Fair-by-design matching

David Garc√≠a-Soriano ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Francesco Bonchi
Abstract

Matching algorithms are used routinely to match donors to recipients for solid organs transplantation, for the assignment of medical residents to hospitals, record linkage in databases, scheduling jobs on machines, network switching, online advertising, and image recognition, among others. Although many optimal solutions may exist to a given matching problem, when the elements that shall or not be included in a solution correspond to individuals, it becomes of paramount importance that the solution be selected fairly.

In this paper we study individual fairness in matching problems. Given that many maximum matchings may exist, each one satisfying a different set of individuals, the only way to guarantee fairness is through randomization. Hence we introduce the distributional maxmin fairness framework which provides, for any given input instance, the strongest guarantee possible simultaneously for all individuals in terms of satisfaction probability (the probability of being matched in the solution). Specifically, a probability distribution over feasible solutions is maxmin-fair if it is not possible to improve the satisfaction probability of any individual without decreasing it for some other individual which is no better off. In the special case of matchings in bipartite graphs, our framework is equivalent to the egalitarian mechanism of Bogomolnaia and Mouline.

Our main contribution is a polynomial-time algorithm for fair matching building on techniques from minimum cuts, and edge-coloring algorithms for regular bipartite graphs, and transversal theory. For bipartite graphs, our algorithm runs in O‚Äã((|V|2+|E|‚Äã|V|2/3)‚ãÖ(log‚Å°|V|)2)ùëÇ‚ãÖsuperscriptùëâ2ùê∏superscriptùëâ23superscriptùëâ2O((|V|^{2}+|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) expected time and scales to graphs with tens of millions of vertices and hundreds of millions of edges. To the best of our knowledge, this provides the first large-scale implementation of the egalitarian mechanism. Our experimental analysis confirms that our method provides stronger satisfaction probability guarantees than non-trivial baselines.

Keywords:
Algorithmic bias fairness matching combinatorial optimization

1 Introduction

Decision-making tools relying on data and quantitative measures have become pervasive in application domains such as education and employment, finance, search and recommendation, policy making, and criminal justice. Awareness and concern about the risks of unfair automated decisions is quickly rising, as it has been argued that decisions informed by data analysis could have inadvertent discriminatory effects due to potential bias existing in the data or encoded in automated decisions. Several reports¬†Obama1 ; Obama2 call for algorithms that are ‚Äúfair by design‚Äù and identify ‚Äúpoorly designed matching systems‚Äù as one of the main flaws of algorithmic decision-making. The way to tackle the ensuing ethical and societal issues has garnered the attention of the research community¬†DworkKeynote . However, despite the fact that matching mechanisms lie at the basis of many automated decision systems, the bulk of the research in the area of algorithmic bias and fairness has mainly focused on avoiding discrimination against a sensitive attribute (i.e., a protected social group) in supervised machine learning¬†fair_ml .

Our work departs from this literature in three main directions: (1) we focus on individual fairness (as opposed to group-level fairness); (2) we focus on bias stemming from the algorithm design itself, rather than the bias existing in the input data; (3) instead of supervised learning we focus on matching problems, where the solution may not be unique and individuals correspond to elements to be included in the solution.

In this setting, the satisfaction (utility) function of each individual is based on whether the individual has been selected or not for inclusion. At the very least, two individuals satisfying all relevant criteria equally well (e.g., having the same skill set) should have, in principle, the same expected utility; moreover, individuals having a wider or a more unique skill set (covering relevant criteria that others can‚Äôt cover), should reasonably be rewarded with higher expected utility. This is often not the case as algorithms may be ‚Äúbiased by design‚Äù: bias may stem from something as petty as the order in which the algorithm chooses to process the list of candidates in its main loop (e.g., by irrelevant attributes such as alphabetical order or application date), or details about the internal workings of the algorithm. The prototypical example of a ‚Äúbiased by design‚Äù algorithm (in a rather extreme way) arises in the context of stable matching (a different problem from the one considered in this paper): the Gale-Shapley algorithm¬†GaleShapley produces a solution which is always the best for every man and the worst for every woman, among all feasible solutions, despite the existence of another solution which lies provably ‚Äúin the middle‚Äù for every man and woman¬†geometry_matchings .

Algorithmic bias and randomization. Consider a job-search setting where we have a certain number of positions and applicants. Assume that each applicant has a binary fitting for each of the positions (either she is fit for the job or not) and a binary satisfaction function (either she is selected or not). This can be modeled as a matching problem in a bipartite graph. Unless a matching covering simultaneously all applicants exists, some of them will have to be left out. An unselected applicant could notice that there are other matchings (even maximum-size matchings) satisfying her. However, any deterministic algorithm is programmed to pick a specific one which may not include her: she might rightfully deem this unfair.

Unlike the Gale-Shapley algorithm, whose bias can be simply characterized by a theorem, for the problems we consider in this paper it may be hard to tell in advance which particular individuals a given algorithm favours. However, the fact that the bias is not easy to pinpoint does not mean it does not exist, just that we do not know what it is.

Since no single candidate solution satisfying all individuals at the same time can exist in general, we turn our attention to randomized algorithms, which make random choices to pick from among several valid solutions.

In our job-search example, imagine there is a single open position and nùëõn applicants fit for it. Intuitively, all applicants are ‚Äúequally qualified‚Äù in this case and the fairest solution would choose one of them uniformly at random, giving each applicant a guaranteed satisfaction (matching) probability of 1/n1ùëõ1/n. However, as the graph between applicants and jobs grows more complex, it becomes unclear how to proceed, or what properties one should demand of a fair distribution of solutions. Our next example illustrates why requiring exactly the same satisfaction probability for all individuals would not make for a good definition.

Example 1 (Satisfaction probability).

Consider the problem of finding a matching on the bipartite graph of Figure 1 between people (on the left) and jobs (on the right). Let ùí∞={a0,a1,a2,a3}ùí∞subscriptùëé0subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëé3{\mathcal{U}}=\{a_{0},a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\} and let ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} denote the set of all possible matchings. An individual u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}} is satisfied by a solution S‚ààùíÆùëÜùíÆS\in{\mathcal{S}} iff it is matched in SùëÜS (i.e., she is selected for the job). Consider the distribution Dùê∑D assigning probability 1313\frac{1}{3} to each of the following solutions: M1={(a0,b0),(a1,b1),(a2,b2)}subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëé0subscriptùëè0subscriptùëé1subscriptùëè1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëè2M_{1}=\{(a_{0},b_{0}),(a_{1},b_{1}),(a_{2},b_{2})\}, M2={(a0,b0),(a1,b1),(a3,b2)}subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëé0subscriptùëè0subscriptùëé1subscriptùëè1subscriptùëé3subscriptùëè2M_{2}=\{(a_{0},b_{0}),(a_{1},b_{1}),(a_{3},b_{2})\}, M3={(a2,b2),(a3,b1)}subscriptùëÄ3subscriptùëé2subscriptùëè2subscriptùëé3subscriptùëè1M_{3}=\{(a_{2},b_{2}),(a_{3},b_{1})\} and zero probability to all the other matchings.

The satisfaction probability of each individual under distribution Dùê∑D is exactly the same, namely 2323\frac{2}{3}.While Dùê∑D might naively look ‚Äúfair‚Äù, notice that the job b0subscriptùëè0b_{0} is left unassigned in M3subscriptùëÄ3M_{3}, despite the existence of a fitting candidate occasionally left unemployed (a0subscriptùëé0a_{0}). This artificially restricts the satisfaction probability of¬†a0subscriptùëé0a_{0}. Observe that, for any matching covering a subset T‚äÜ{a1,a2,a3}ùëásubscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëé3T\subseteq\{a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\}, there is another matching covering T‚à™{a0}ùëásubscriptùëé0T\cup\{a_{0}\}. So a0subscriptùëé0a_{0} can always be satisfied without impacting anyone else‚Äôs chances, hence any reasonable solution should match a0subscriptùëé0a_{0} with probability 1. Other applicants will have lower satisfaction probability though (as no matching can satisfy all of a1,a2subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2a_{1},a_{2} and a3subscriptùëé3a_{3} at the same time).

The insight from Example¬†1 leads us to the key definition of our work. Our aim is to provide, on any given input instance, the strongest guarantee possible for all individuals, in terms of satisfaction probability. We thus introduce the distributional maxmin fairness framework. Informally, a distribution over matchings is maxmin-fair if it is impossible to improve the satisfaction probability of any individual without decreasing it for some other individual which is no better off (see Section¬†2 for a formal definition).

Example 2 (Maxmin-fair distribution).

Consider Example¬†1 again. A distribution assigning non-zero probability to a solution not covering a0subscriptùëé0a_{0} (such as M3subscriptùëÄ3M_{3}) cannot be maxmin-fair, as otherwise one can increase the satisfaction probability of a0subscriptùëé0a_{0} without detriment to anyone else. The distribution F1subscriptùêπ1F_{1} choosing from among M1,M2,M4subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ4M_{1},M_{2},M_{4} and M5subscriptùëÄ5M_{5} with probability 13,16,16,1313161613\frac{1}{3},\frac{1}{6},\frac{1}{6},\frac{1}{3}, respectively, is maxmin-fair. The satisfaction probabilities of a0,a1,a2subscriptùëé0subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2a_{0},a_{1},a_{2} and a3subscriptùëé3a_{3} are then 1,23,23,2312323231,\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3}. Any attempt to match, say, a1subscriptùëé1a_{1} with probability >23absent23>\frac{2}{3} will necessarily result in satisfaction probability <23absent23<\frac{2}{3} for a2subscriptùëé2a_{2} or a3subscriptùëé3a_{3}. Another maxmin-fair distribution is, e.g., the distribution F2subscriptùêπ2F_{2} choosing uniformly at random from among M1,M2subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2M_{1},M_{2} and M5subscriptùëÄ5M_{5}.

Overview of our contributions. The contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    We introduce and characterize the distributional maxmin-fairness framework providing, on any given problem instance, the strongest guarantee possible for all individuals, in terms of satisfaction probability (Section 2). While in this paper, for sake of simplicity of presentation, we focus on matching problems, our definition applies to a wider variety of problems (such as those listed in Example¬†5).

  • ‚Ä¢

    In Section 3, we show that when the structure of valid solutions forms a matroid (which is the case for matchings), maxmin-fairness minimizes the largest inequality gap in satisfaction probabilities between all pairs of individuals, among all Pareto-efficient distributions (Theorem¬†3.2). We also observe that for such problems the ‚Äúprice of fairness‚Äù is zero: maxmin fairness is attainable at no cost in solution size.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We give a characterization of the ‚Äúdegree of fairness‚Äù attainable in any bipartite matching instance (Theorem¬†A.2) and any matroid problem instance (Theorem¬†A.2), generalizing the classical marriage theorem due to Hall¬†hall .

  • ‚Ä¢

    We apply our framework to matching problems in bipartite graphs (Sections¬†4 and 5), leading to our main contribution: an exact algorithm for maxmin-fair bipartite matching with running time O‚Äã((|V|2+|E|‚Äã|V|2/3)‚ãÖ(log‚Å°|V|)2)ùëÇ‚ãÖsuperscriptùëâ2ùê∏superscriptùëâ23superscriptùëâ2O((|V|^{2}+|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) (Theorem¬†5.1). We also obtain a polynomial time maxmin-fair algorithm for matching in general graphs by a reduction to the aforementioned bipartite case (Theorem¬†6.3).

  • ‚Ä¢

    We discuss how to achieve full transparency for real-world deployment of our framework (Section 7). The discussion leads to the problem of producing a maxmin-fair distribution with small support, for which we offer an approach making small modifications to our algorithm.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Our experiments (Section¬†8) show that our algorithm performs faster in practice than its theoretical running time and scales to graphs with tens of millions of vertices and hundreds of millions of edges, taking only a few minutes on a simple architecture. Our analysis confirms that our method provides stronger satisfaction probability guarantees than non-trivial baselines.

2 Problem definition

In this section we provide the key definition of our distributional maxmin-fairness framework, considering a very general search problem instance ‚Ñê=(ùí∞,ùíÆ)‚Ñêùí∞ùíÆ{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}) defined over a finite set of individuals ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} and where ùíÆ‚â†‚àÖùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}\neq\emptyset denotes the set of feasible solutions for the problem instance ‚Ñê‚Ñê{\mathcal{I}}. (For example, instance ‚Ñê‚Ñê{\mathcal{I}} could represent a bipartite graph between jobs and a set ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} of applicants, and ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} the set of all matchings.) We assume that for every solution S‚ààùíÆùëÜùíÆS\in{\mathcal{S}}, each individual u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}} is either fully satisfied or fully dissatisfied, and this is the only property of the solution we are concerned with. Thus, for the sake of simplicity, we will identify each solution in ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} with the subset of users satisfied by it, so ùíÆ‚äÜ2ùí∞ùíÆsuperscript2ùí∞{\mathcal{S}}\subseteq 2^{{\mathcal{U}}}. Note that ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} is defined implicitly by the structure of the problem, and not explicitly encoded in the input.

Given ‚Ñê‚Ñê{\mathcal{I}}, our problem is to return an element of ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} while providing a fairness guarantee to all individuals in ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}}. Since in general no single candidate solution satisfying all u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}} at the same time exists (ùí∞‚àâSùí∞ùëÜ{\mathcal{U}}\notin S), we seek a randomized algorithm ùíúùíú{\mathcal{A}} that, for any given problem instance ‚Ñê‚Ñê{\mathcal{I}}, always halts and selects one solution ùíú‚Äã(‚Ñê)ùíú‚Ñê{\mathcal{A}}({\mathcal{I}}) from ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}. Thus ùíúùíú{\mathcal{A}} induces a probability distribution Dùê∑D over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}: PrD‚Å°[S]=Pr‚Å°[ùíú‚Äã(‚Ñê)=S]subscriptPrùê∑ùëÜPrùíú‚ÑêùëÜ\Pr_{D}[S]=\Pr[{\mathcal{A}}({\mathcal{I}})=S] for each S‚ààùíÆùëÜùíÆS\in{\mathcal{S}}. The satisfaction probability of each individual u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}} under Dùê∑D is defined by D‚Äã[u]=PrS‚àºD‚Å°[u‚ààS].ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢subscriptPrsimilar-toùëÜùê∑ùë¢ùëÜD[u]=\Pr_{S\sim D}[u\in S].

Based on the insight from Example¬†1, we next provide the key definition of our work. Informally, a distribution over solutions is maxmin-fair if it is impossible to improve the satisfaction probability of any individual without decreasing it for some other individual which is no better off.

Definition 1 (Maxmin-fairness).
A distribution FùêπF over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} is maxmin-fair for ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} if for all distributions Dùê∑D over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} and all u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}}, D‚Äã[u]ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢\displaystyle{D}[{u}] >F‚Äã[u]‚üπ‚àÉv‚ààùí∞‚à£D‚Äã[v]<F‚Äã[v]‚â§F‚Äã[u].absentùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢ùë£conditionalùí∞ùê∑delimited-[]ùë£ùêπdelimited-[]ùë£ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢\displaystyle>{F}[{u}]\implies\exists v\in{\mathcal{U}}\mid{D}[{v}]<{F}[{v}]\leq{F}[{u}]. (1) Similarly, a randomized algorithm is maxmin-fair if it induces a maxmin-fair distribution.

Finding a maxmin-fair distribution involves solving a continuous optimization problem over (infinitely many) distributions over the set ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} of valid solutions (which is commonly exponential in size). The challenge we face is thus how to design an efficient randomized algorithm inducing a maxmin-fair distribution.

Problem 1.

For a given search problem, design a randomized algorithm ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} which always terminates and such that, for each instance ‚Ñê=(ùí∞,ùíÆ)‚Ñêùí∞ùíÆ{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}), the distribution of ùíú‚Äã(‚Ñê)ùíú‚Ñê{\mathcal{A}}({\mathcal{I}}) is maxmin-fair for ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}.

While our definition applies to a wider variety of search problems, in this paper, for sake of simplicity of presentation, we solve Problem¬†1 in the case where the search problem is a matching problem in a graph. Let us specify what the sets ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} of users and ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} of solutions are in this case (Table¬†1 below summarizes the notation used throughout the paper).

Let G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) be an unweighted simple graph. A matching in Gùê∫G is a set of vertex-disjoint edges of Gùê∫G. A maximum matching is a matching of largest size. The matching MùëÄM covers a vertex v‚ààVùë£ùëâv\in V if vùë£v is incident to some edge in MùëÄM. A set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V is matchable if there is a matching of Gùê∫G covering all of SùëÜS. For S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V, define œÅG‚Äã(S)subscriptùúåùê∫ùëÜ\rho_{G}(S) as the size of the largest matchable subset of SùëÜS; then œÅG‚Äã(V)subscriptùúåùê∫ùëâ\rho_{G}(V) is the size of the maximum matching of Gùê∫G. Denote by ŒìG‚Äã(S)subscriptŒìùê∫ùëÜ\Gamma_{G}(S) the set of neighbours of SùëÜS in Gùê∫G. We will drop the Gùê∫G subscript when no confusion may arise.

In the fair matching problem, the input is a graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) and a set ùí∞‚äÜVùí∞ùëâ{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V of users. Following our assumption of binary satisfaction, user u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}} is satisfied by a matching MùëÄM if uùë¢u is covered by MùëÄM. The set ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} of valid solutions is the set of matchable subsets of¬†ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}}. The set ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} is not part of the input given to the algorithm, but implicitly defined by Gùê∫G and ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}}.

While the results provided in Section 3 hold for fair-matching on a general graph, the algorithms developed in Sections¬†4 and 5 are for the interesting special case of one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, i.e., where Gùê∫G is bipartite (with bipartition V=L‚Äã‚à™Àô‚ÄãRùëâùêøÀôùëÖV=L\ \dot{\cup}\ R) and the set of users is given by ùí∞=Lùí∞ùêø{\mathcal{U}}=L. By solving the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, we also obtain a polynomial time maxmin-fair algorithm for matching in general graphs by means of a reduction to the bipartite case (see Theorem¬†6.3).

3 Fairness and social inequality

In this section we present several properties of maxmin-fair distributions. These are of independent interest as they provide alternative definitions of maxmin-fairness (Theorems¬†3.1 and¬†3.2) which are arguably just as natural as Definition¬†1; moreover, the latter offers insights into the inequality distribution properties of maxmin-fairness. Some results are only stated here; their proofs may be found in Appendix¬†A.

3.1 Basic properties of maxmin-fair distributions

An important preliminary observation is that maxmin-fair distributions are unique as far as satisfaction probabilities go, even though several ways may exist to achieve the optimal satisfaction probabilities.

Lemma 1 ().

Let FùêπF and Dùê∑D be two maxmin-fair distributions. Then F‚Äã[u]=D‚Äã[u]ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢{F}[{u}]={D}[{u}] for all u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}}.

Example 3.

In Example¬†2 we gave two maxmin-fair distributions, F1subscriptùêπ1F_{1} and F2subscriptùêπ2F_{2}, which are obtained by combining maximum matchings in different ways, but both satisfy F1‚Äã[a0]=F2‚Äã[a0]=1subscriptùêπ1delimited-[]subscriptùëé0subscriptùêπ2delimited-[]subscriptùëé01{F_{1}}[{a_{0}}]={F_{2}}[{a_{0}}]=1 and F1‚Äã[x]=F2‚Äã[x]=23subscriptùêπ1delimited-[]ùë•subscriptùêπ2delimited-[]ùë•23{F_{1}}[{x}]={F_{2}}[{x}]=\frac{2}{3} for x‚àà{a1,a2,a3}ùë•subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëé3x\in\{a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\}.

Given a distribution Dùê∑D over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}, write D‚Üë=(Œª1,‚Ä¶,Œªn){D\uparrow\,}=(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n}) for the vector of satisfaction probabilities (D‚Äã[u])u‚ààùí∞subscriptùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢ùë¢ùí∞(D[u])_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}} sorted in increasing order. Let ‚âªsucceeds\succ denote the lexicographical order of vectors: (v1,‚Ä¶,vn)‚âª(w1,‚Ä¶,wn)succeedssubscriptùë£1‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëõsubscriptùë§1‚Ä¶subscriptùë§ùëõ(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})\succ(w_{1},\ldots,w_{n}) iff there is some index i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n] such that vj=wjsubscriptùë£ùëósubscriptùë§ùëóv_{j}=w_{j} for all j<iùëóùëñj<i and vi>wisubscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëñv_{i}>w_{i} (the relations ‚™∞,‚â∫succeeds-or-equalsprecedes\succeq,\prec and ‚™Øprecedes-or-equals\preceq are defined similarly). The following holds.

Theorem 3.1 ().

A distribution FùêπF is maxmin-fair if and only if F‚Üë‚™∞D‚Üë{F\uparrow\,}\succeq{D\uparrow\,} for all distributions Dùê∑D over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}.

In other words, a maxmin-fair distribution maximizes the smallest satisfaction probability; subject to that, it maximizes the second-smallest satisfaction probability, and so on.

Example 4.

In Examples¬†1 and ¬†2 we have F1‚Üë=F2‚Üë=(1,23,23,23)‚âªD‚Üë=(23,23,23,23){F_{1}\uparrow\,}={F_{2}\uparrow\,}=(1,\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3})\succ{D\uparrow\,}=(\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3},\frac{2}{3}). As D‚Üë‚Üëùê∑absent{D\uparrow\,} is not lexicographically maximal, it cannot be maxmin-fair; whereas F1‚Üë‚Üësubscriptùêπ1absent{F_{1}\uparrow\,} can be shown to be lexicographically maximal, and hence F1subscriptùêπ1F_{1} is maxmin-fair.

An important observation is that a maxmin-fair distribution always exists for any search problem instance with a feasible solution:

Corollary 1.

Given a search problem instance ‚Ñê=(ùí∞,ùíÆ)‚Ñêùí∞ùíÆ{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}), a maxmin-fair distribution always exists.

Proof.

The probability vectors defining distributions over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} form a non-empty compact set, and the mapping from such vectors to their corresponding sorted satisfaction vectors is continuous, so the claim follows from Weirstrass theorem. ‚àé

3.2 Matroid problems

Theorem 3.1 above provides a definition of maxmin-fairness alternative to Definition¬†1. At the end of this section (Theorem¬†3.2) we provide a second alternative definition characterizing the inequality properties of the distribution of satisfaction probabilities, i.e., the differences between the satisfaction of the least and most satisfied individuals. It turns out that for a large class of problems, this difference is minimized in a maxmin-fair distribution, making the maxmin-fair distribution the most equitable. However this does not hold in general for all search problems.

To be able to state the class of problems for which Theorem¬†3.2 holds, we need to review the concept of matroids. Many search and optimization problems can be formulated in terms of matroids; they also provide a convenient framework to state and simplify the proofs of some of our results.

Definition 2 (Matroid problem).

Let LùêøL be a finite set. A matroid with ground set LùêøL is a non-empty collection MùëÄM of subsets of LùêøL satisfying the following two properties: (1) if A‚ààMùê¥ùëÄA\in M and B‚äÜAùêµùê¥B\subseteq A, then B‚ààMùêµùëÄB\in M; (2) for any X‚äÜLùëãùêøX\subseteq L, all maximal subsets of XùëãX (with respect to set inclusion) belonging to MùëÄM have the same size.

A search problem is a matroid problem if for any instance ‚Ñê=(ùí∞,ùíÆ)‚Ñêùí∞ùíÆ{\mathcal{I}}=({\mathcal{U}},{\mathcal{S}}), the set ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} is a matroid. The elements of a matroid MùëÄM are called independent sets. The maximal elements of MùëÄM are called bases. All bases have the same size. The rank function of MùëÄM is œÅM‚Äã(S)=max‚Å°{|X|‚à£X‚äÜS,X‚ààM}subscriptùúåùëÄùëÜconditionalùëãùëãùëÜùëãùëÄ\rho_{M}(S)=\max\{|X|\mid X\subseteq S,X\in M\}.

Example 5.

The following are matroids (see¬†lawler_book ):

  • ‚Ä¢

    The collection of sets of matchable vertices in a graph¬†matching_book . This well-known result follows from a theorem of Berge¬†berge_matchings that we may extend any matchable set of vertices to a matchable set of maximum size. By contrast, the collections of sets of edges forming a matching is not a matroid.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The collection of sets of vertices in a graph for which edge-disjoint paths from another single specified vertex exist.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The collection of linearly independent sets of vectors over a finite vector space.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The collection of forests (acyclic sets of edges) in a graph.

The search problems corresponding to finding any of the above are matroid problems.

Notice that any set XùëãX appearing with non-zero probability in a maxmin-fair distribution must be maximum in size; otherwise, by property (2) in Definition¬†2, XùëãX is not maximal so we could replace XùëãX with some strict superset Y‚äãXùëãùëåY\supsetneq X, which can only increase the satisfaction probability of every u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L. It is in this sense that the ‚Äúprice of fairness‚Äù is zero for matroid problems: the support of a maxmin-fair distribution consists only of solutions of maximum size, so it is never necessary to trade fairness for solution size. In particular this holds for matching problems as well.

3.3 Minmax-fairness

By definition, maxmin-fair distributions give the highest possible satisfaction probabilities to the worst-off individuals. To investigate the inequality properties of these, we introduce a dual notion of minmax-fair distributions, which by contrast give the lowest possible satisfaction probabilities to the best-off individuals. It turns out that for matroid problems both notions coincide, provided that we exclude Pareto-inefficient distributions.

Definition 3 (Pareto efficiency).

A distribution Eùê∏E is (ex-ante) Pareto-efficient if there is no distribution Dùê∑D such that D‚Äã[u]‚â•E‚Äã[u]ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢ùê∏delimited-[]ùë¢{D}[{u}]\geq{E}[{u}] for all u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}} and D‚Äã[u]>E‚Äã[u]ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢ùê∏delimited-[]ùë¢{D}[{u}]>{E}[{u}] for at least one u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}}.

The notion of Pareto-efficiency expresses the impossibility of improving the satisfaction probability of some user without detriment to anyone else. Clearly any maxmin-fair distribution is Pareto-efficient, hence any solution in its support is maximal (with regard to set inclusion).

The notion of minmax-fairness outlined above requires that no user satisfaction can be decreased without increasing that of another user which is no worse off, or losing Pareto-efficiency.

Definition 4.

A Pareto-efficient distribution FùêπF over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} is minmax-Pareto (or minmax fair) for ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} if for all Pareto-efficient distributions Dùê∑D over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} and all u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}}, it holds that

D‚Äã[u]ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢\displaystyle{D}[{u}] <F‚Äã[u]‚üπ‚àÉv‚ààùí∞‚à£D‚Äã[v]>‚ÄãF‚Äã[v]‚â•F‚Äã[u].inner-productùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢ùë£ùí∞ùê∑delimited-[]ùë£ùêπdelimited-[]ùë£ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢\displaystyle<{F}[{u}]\implies\exists v\in{\mathcal{U}}\mid{D}[{v}]>{F}[{v}]\geq{F}[{u}].

Requiring Pareto-efficiency is redundant for maxmin-fairness, but crucial for minmax-Pareto efficiency; without it, the definition would be met by a distribution of solutions satisfying nobody (for example, a solution which always returns the empty matching).

In Appendix¬†A we present analogues to Lemma¬†1 and Theorem¬†3.1 (Lemma¬†1 and Theorem¬†A.1) for minmax-fairness.

3.4 Inequality properties

The main result of this section, Theorem¬†3.2 is that, for matroid problems, the notions of minmax fairness and maxmin fairness coincide; intuitively, any excess satisfaction probability for the best-off user can be taken away from him and redistributed to others. This also implies that the maxmin-fair solution minimizes the largest gap in satisfaction probabilities; among those, it minimizes the second-largest gap, etc.

Definition 5.

The sorted inequality vector of a distribution Dùê∑D over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}, written D‚â†‚Üìsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑‚Üì{D}_{\neq}^{\downarrow}, is the vector of all pairwise differences in the satisfaction probabilities of the elements of ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} under Dùê∑D, sorted in decreasing order.

Theorem 3.2 ().

For matroid problems, the following are equivalent: (1) Dùê∑D is maxmin-fair; (2) Dùê∑D is minmax-Pareto; (3) Dùê∑D is Pareto-efficient and D‚â†‚Üì‚™ØE‚â†‚Üìprecedes-or-equalssuperscriptsubscriptùê∑‚Üìsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏‚Üì{D}_{\neq}^{\downarrow}\preceq{E}_{\neq}^{\downarrow} for all Pareto-efficient distributions Eùê∏E over ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}.

The proof may be found in Appendix¬†A.

Note that this result does not hold in general for non-matroid problems; the following shows a counterexample.

Example 6.

Consider the problem instance where the set of individuals is ùí∞={0,1,2,3}ùí∞0123{\mathcal{U}}=\{0,1,2,3\} and the set of feasible solutions is ùíÆ={{0,1},{1,3},{0,2,3}}ùíÆ0113023{\mathcal{S}}=\{\{0,1\},\{1,3\},\{0,2,3\}\}. Here elements 111 and 222 never appear together in a solution, so the minimum satisfaction probability cannot exceed 1212\frac{1}{2}. In order to achieve 1212\frac{1}{2} we need to choose {0,2,3}023\{0,2,3\} with probability exactly 1212\frac{1}{2}; this fixes the satisfaction probabilities of 222 and 111 to 1212\frac{1}{2}, and to maximize the second-smallest probability we need to pick {0,1}01\{0,1\} and {1,3}13\{1,3\} with probability 1414\frac{1}{4} each. This is the maxmin-fair distribution D1subscriptùê∑1D_{1} and its maximum inequality is 1414\frac{1}{4}. However, a similar argument shows that the minmax-fair distribution D2subscriptùê∑2D_{2} is different: it uses each element of ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}} with probability 1313\frac{1}{3} and has maximum inequality 1313\frac{1}{3}.

Note that in this case one may verify that D1subscriptùê∑1D_{1} still minimizes maximum inequality, but by considering the complements of each element of ùíÆùíÆ{\mathcal{S}}, one can give a similar example where the maxmin-fair distribution does not minimize inequality.

4 A polynomial-time algorithm for maxmin-fair matching

In this section we present our main contribution: a polynomial-time algorithm for maxmin-fair matching. We present our algorithm for the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem. This is the special case of fair matching where:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Gùê∫G is bipartite (with bipartition V=L‚Äã‚à™Àô‚ÄãRùëâùêøÀôùëÖV=L\ \dot{\cup}\ R),

  • ‚Ä¢

    the set of users is ùí∞=Lùí∞ùêø{\mathcal{U}}=L,

  • ‚Ä¢

    there is a maximum matching covers all the right-side vertices but not all the left-side vertices (i.e., œÅ‚Äã(L)=|R|<|L|ùúåùêøùëÖùêø\rho(L)=|R|<|L|),

  • ‚Ä¢

    there are no degree-0 vertices (which can always be removed).

This setting corresponds to the job-search setting that we use in our examples throughout the paper. We will see later (Section¬†5.2) that the general fair matching problem in non-bipartite graphs, with arbitrary user sets ùí∞‚äÜVùí∞ùëâ{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V and with no further restrictions, can be reduced to this special case in polynomial time. Before presenting the building blocks of our algorithm in full detail, we provide an overview of our techniques. Some results are only stated here; their proofs may be found in Appendix¬†B.

4.1 Overview of our techniques

We next provide an overview of how we obtain our main result: an efficient algorithm for maxmin-fair bipartite matching.

  1. (1)

    The first ingredient (Section 4.2) is a characterization of the fairness parameter, i.e., the maximum satisfaction probability which can be guaranteed for every user. By using Hall‚Äôs theorem we prove (Corollary¬†2) that the fairness parameter is determined by a ‚Äúblocking‚Äù set of vertices with the smallest neighborhood-to-size ratio. Unfortunately, the proof does not lead to an efficient algorithm to find this set.

  2. (2)

    Thus we proceed to write down a linear program for a fractional variant of the problem (Section 4.3). Inspired by a technique developed by Charikar¬†charikar for the densest-subgraph problem, we show (Lemma¬†3) that any fractional solution can be leveraged to find a blocking set of vertices. The neighbors of the blocking set cannot be matched to any vertex outside the blocking set in any maxmin-fair distribution. We use this fact to argue inductively (Theorem¬†4.3) the existence of a ‚Äúfair decomposition‚Äù of the set of left vertices with the following property: vertices on higher levels can be allowed larger satisfaction probabilities, regardless of which edges are used to match the vertices on lower levels.

  3. (3)

    Having computed the assignment probabilities xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} (the probability of each pair of vertices being matched) of some maxmin-fair distribution within each block in the decomposition, we can turn each of them into an actual distribution of matchings by finding the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition of a doubly-stochastic matrix. Then we combine them into a single distribution.

  4. (4)

    To obtain our faster algorithm (which also returns the exact optimal solution), we avoid the use of linear programming and instead present a technique to find several blocks in parallel with a single min-cut computation (Section¬†5). We show that a logarithmic number of minimum cut computations suffice to obtain the fair decomposition in full. Then we argue that given the decomposition and satisfaction probabilities, the required distribution of matchings can be found by coloring the edges of an appropriately constructed regular bipartite graph, for which task we leverage the fast algorithm of Goel et al.¬†perfect_nlogn .

4.2 Fairness parameter

We next ask the following important question: what is the minimum satisfaction probability œÄ‚Äã(G)ùúãùê∫\pi(G) of a maxmin-fair distribution for Gùê∫G? Hall‚Äôs marriage theorem gives a necessary and sufficient condition for the existence of a matching covering the whole of LùêøL, which is equivalent to having œÄ‚Äã(G)=1ùúãùê∫1\pi(G)=1.

Theorem 4.1 (Hall¬†hall ).

In a bipartite graph with bipartition (L,R)ùêøùëÖ(L,R), the set LùêøL is matchable if and only if |Œì‚Äã(S)|‚â•|S|ŒìùëÜùëÜ|\Gamma(S)|\geq|S| for all S‚äÜLùëÜùêøS\subseteq L.

Proceeding similarly, we obtain a set of vertex-disjoint matchings in G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} such that their union is a matching X‚Ä≤superscriptùëã‚Ä≤X^{\prime} in G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} covering L‚Ä≤superscriptùêø‚Ä≤L^{\prime}. Furthermore, each u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L is covered in exactly nusubscriptùëõùë¢n_{u} of these, since X‚Ä≤superscriptùëã‚Ä≤X^{\prime} covers L‚Ä≤superscriptùêø‚Ä≤L^{\prime}. Thus the uniform distribution over X1,‚Ä¶,XMsubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëÄX_{1},\ldots,X_{M} yields coverage probability nu/M=Œ±usubscriptùëõùë¢ùëÄsubscriptùõºùë¢n_{u}/M=\alpha_{u} for each u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L. ‚àé

The proof gives a maxmin-fair distribution which is uniform over a multiset of MùëÄM matchings, but MùëÄM may be fairly large, as large as 2Œ©‚Äã(|ùí∞|)superscript2Œ©ùí∞2^{\Omega(\sqrt{|{\mathcal{U}}|})} in some instances.

Corollary 2.

The minimum satisfaction probability in a maxmin-fair distribution for the one-sided bipartite matching problem is

œÄ‚Äã(G)=min‚Å°{|Œì‚Äã(S)||S|‚à£‚àÖ‚â†S‚äÜL}.ùúãùê∫conditionalŒìùëÜùëÜùëÜùêø\pi(G)=\min\left\{\frac{|\Gamma(S)|}{|S|}\mid\emptyset\neq S\subseteq L\right\}.
Proof.

Fix a parameter Œª‚àà[0,1]ùúÜ01\lambda\in[0,1]. By Theorem¬†4.2, a distribution with satisfaction probability at least ŒªùúÜ\lambda for all LùêøL exists if and only if Œì‚Äã(S)‚â•Œª‚Äã|S|ŒìùëÜùúÜùëÜ\Gamma(S)\geq\lambda|S| for all S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V. ‚àé

In Appendix¬†B we prove a dual result for the maximum satisfaction probability:

Corollary 3.

The maximum satisfaction probability in a maxmin-fair distribution for the one-sided bipartite matching problem is

Œ†‚Äã(G)=max‚Å°{|Œì‚Äã(L)|‚àí|Œì‚Äã(S)||L‚àñS|‚à£S‚ääL}.Œ†ùê∫conditionalŒìùêøŒìùëÜùêøùëÜùëÜùêø\Pi(G)=\max\left\{\frac{|\Gamma(L)|-|\Gamma(S)|}{|L\setminus S|}\mid S\subsetneq L\right\}.

4.3 A compact LP formulation for the fairness parameter

Below we write a linear program for computing œÄ‚Äã(G)ùúãùê∫\pi(G).

In combination with Corollary¬†2, these two lemmas yield an effective method of computing œÄ‚Äã(G)ùúãùê∫\pi(G):

Corollary 4.

In the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, the fairness parameter œÄ‚Äã(G)ùúãùê∫\pi(G) is equal to the optimum value of the LP in¬†(3).

4.4 Fair decompositions

The next ingredient towards an efficient algorithm is to find a decomposition of LùêøL according to different levels of satisfaction probability in the maxmin-fair distribution. In Figure¬†2, the set of left vertices with smallest neighbor-to-size ratio is the set B1={a5,a4}subscriptùêµ1subscriptùëé5subscriptùëé4B_{1}=\{a_{5},a_{4}\}, with Œì‚Äã(B1)={b3}Œìsubscriptùêµ1subscriptùëè3\Gamma(B_{1})=\{b_{3}\}. By Corollary¬†2, the fairness parameter of the graph in the picture is 1212\frac{1}{2}. But in order to actually match a5subscriptùëé5a_{5} and a4subscriptùëé4a_{4} with probability 1212\frac{1}{2}, b3subscriptùëè3b_{3} must be matched to one of the two every single time. Hence the edge (a3,b3)subscriptùëé3subscriptùëè3(a_{3},b_{3}) can never be used to in a maxmin-maxmin-fair solution. After removing B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1} and Œì‚Äã(B1)Œìsubscriptùêµ1\Gamma(B_{1}) from the graph, the next set of left vertices with smallest neighbor-to-size ratio is the set B2={a1,a2,a3}subscriptùêµ2subscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëé3B_{2}=\{a_{1},a_{2},a_{3}\} and again we find that edge (a0,b1)subscriptùëé0subscriptùëè1(a_{0},b_{1}) cannot be used. The last set we find in this way is B3={a0}subscriptùêµ3subscriptùëé0B_{3}=\{a_{0}\}.

We refer to B1,B2,B3subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2subscriptùêµ3B_{1},B_{2},B_{3} as the blocks of the fair decomposition; and to the increasing sequence of sets S1=B1,S2=B1‚à™B2formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÜ1subscriptùêµ1subscriptùëÜ2subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2S_{1}=B_{1},S_{2}=B_{1}\cup B_{2} and S3=B1‚à™B2‚à™B3subscriptùëÜ3subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2subscriptùêµ3S_{3}=B_{1}\cup B_{2}\cup B_{3} as the fairly isolated sets. This motivates the following definitions.

For A‚äÜLùê¥ùêøA\subseteq L, denote by G|A|ùê∫ùê¥G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{A}}$}} the subgraph of Gùê∫G induced by A‚à™Œì‚Äã(A)ùê¥Œìùê¥A\cup\Gamma(A), and by G/Aùê∫ùê¥G/A the subgraph of Gùê∫G induced by (L‚à™R)‚àñ(A‚à™Œì‚Äã(A))ùêøùëÖùê¥Œìùê¥(L\cup R)\setminus(A\cup\Gamma(A)). Intuitively, G|A|ùê∫ùê¥G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{A}}$}} represents the subproblem where only the elements of Aùê¥A are important, and G/Aùê∫ùê¥G/A represents the subproblem of G|A¬Ø|ùê∫¬Øùê¥G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{\overline{A}}}$}} where the use of neighbours of Aùê¥A is disallowed. For any subgraph HùêªH of Gùê∫G, let œÄ‚Äã(H)ùúãùêª\pi(H) (resp., Œ†‚Äã(H)Œ†ùêª\Pi(H)) be the minimum (resp., maximum) satisfaction probability of an element of V‚Äã(H)‚à©LùëâùêªùêøV(H)\cap L in a maxmin-fair distribution. The nonempty set X‚äÜLùëãùêøX\subseteq L is fairly isolated if Œ†‚Äã(G|X)<œÄ‚Äã(G/X)Œ†|ùê∫ùëãùúãùê∫ùëã\Pi(G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{X}}$}})<\pi(G/X) or X=LùëãùêøX=L. This means that every u‚àâXùë¢ùëãu\notin X has guaranteed satisfaction larger than the largest maxmin-fair satisfaction inside XùëãX, even if we remove all possibly conflicting edges from XùëãX to¬†Œì‚Äã(X)Œìùëã\Gamma(X).

Finding fairly isolated sets enables a ‚Äúdivide and conquer‚Äù strategy to find maxmin-fair distributions, since it turns out that matchings used inside XùëãX have no bearing on the satisfactions needed for users in L‚àñXùêøùëãL\setminus X. For example, if we can determine that the set B1‚à™B2subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2B_{1}\cup B_{2} is fairly isolated, then we can work independently on B1‚à™B2subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2B_{1}\cup B_{2} and B3subscriptùêµ3B_{3} and combine the distributions found.

With this in mind, we are ready to state our fair decomposition theorem, proved in Appendix¬†B:

Theorem 4.3.

The fairly isolated sets form a chain S1‚äÜS2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚äÜSk‚àí1‚äÜSk=LsubscriptùëÜ1subscriptùëÜ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜùëò1subscriptùëÜùëòùêøS_{1}\subseteq S_{2}\ldots\subseteq S_{k-1}\subseteq S_{k}=L. The following hold for all i=1,‚Ä¶,kùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëòi=1,\ldots,k:

  1. (a)

    Bi‚Äã¬†is the maximal set¬†‚ÄãX‚äÜL‚àñSi‚Äã¬†minimizing¬†‚Äã|Œì‚Äã(X‚à™Si)|‚àí|Œì‚Äã(Si)||X|.subscriptùêµùëñ¬†is the maximal set¬†ùëãùêøsubscriptùëÜùëñ¬†minimizing¬†ŒìùëãsubscriptùëÜùëñŒìsubscriptùëÜùëñùëãB_{i}\text{ is the maximal set }X\subseteq L\setminus S_{i}\text{ minimizing }\frac{|\Gamma(X\cup S_{i})|-|\Gamma(S_{i})|}{|X|}.
