    The satisfaction probability of every v‚ààBiùë£subscriptùêµùëñv\in B_{i} in any maxmin-fair distribution is Œªi=|Œì‚Äã(Bi)‚àñŒì‚Äã(Si‚àí1)||Bi|subscriptùúÜùëñŒìsubscriptùêµùëñŒìsubscriptùëÜùëñ1subscriptùêµùëñ\lambda_{i}=\frac{|\Gamma(B_{i})\setminus\Gamma(S_{i-1})|}{|B_{i}|}, and any w‚ààŒì‚Äã(Bi)‚àñŒì‚Äã(Si‚àí1)ùë§ŒìsubscriptùêµùëñŒìsubscriptùëÜùëñ1w\in\Gamma(B_{i})\setminus\Gamma(S_{i-1}) is matched to some u‚ààBiùë¢subscriptùêµùëñu\in B_{i} with probability 1.

We call B1,‚Ä¶,Bksubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëòB_{1},\ldots,B_{k} the blocks in the fair decomposition of¬†Gùê∫G.

4.5 Description of the basic algorithm

Theorem¬†4.3 and Lemma¬†3 suggest a line of attack to solve the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, outlined in Algorithm¬†1 below. First, find the blocks B1,‚Ä¶,Bksubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëòB_{1},\ldots,B_{k} in a fair decomposition. Second, find a maxmin-fair distribution111Each of these distributions can be represented by a list of pairs (p‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãb‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãi‚Äãl‚Äãi‚Äãt‚Äãy,m‚Äãa‚Äãt‚Äãc‚Äãh‚Äãi‚Äãn‚Äãg)ùëùùëüùëúùëèùëéùëèùëñùëôùëñùë°ùë¶ùëöùëéùë°ùëê‚Ñéùëñùëõùëî(probability,matching), with the probabilities being non-negative and summing up to 1. For our second algorithm a simpler representation is possible: the distribution of matchings Disubscriptùê∑ùëñD_{i} within each block (but not for the whole graph) is uniform over some small multiset of matchings. Disubscriptùê∑ùëñD_{i} for each block BisubscriptùêµùëñB_{i}, using only edges that do not ‚Äúcross to neighbors of lower blocks‚Äù (i.e., no edge is allowed from u‚ààBiùë¢subscriptùêµùëñu\in B_{i} to v‚ààŒì‚Äã(Bj)ùë£Œìsubscriptùêµùëóv\in\Gamma(B_{j}) where j<iùëóùëñj<i). Finally, combine the distributions into a single maxmin-fair distribution Dùê∑D, and draw a matching from it. Both our algorithms follow this general outline; they differ in how to perform steps 1 and 2. (We will discuss later (Section¬†7) an alternative implementation of step 3 which leads to distributions over a smaller number of matchings.)

Next we give the details of our first algorithm (Algorithm¬†2).

Step 1: Finding a fair decomposition. We will find the blocks in a bottom-up manner. To find the first block, observe the following:

Lemma 4.

The maximal set minimizing |Œì‚Äã(X)|/|X|Œìùëãùëã|\Gamma(X)|/|X| is the union of all non-empty sets XùëãX minimizing |Œì‚Äã(X)|/|X|Œìùëãùëã|\Gamma(X)|/|X|.

Proof.

It suffices to show that if X,YùëãùëåX,Y are non-empty sets minimizing |Œì‚Äã(X)|/|X|Œìùëãùëã|\Gamma(X)|/|X|, then X‚à™YùëãùëåX\cup Y also minimizes |Œì‚Äã(X)|/|X|Œìùëãùëã|\Gamma(X)|/|X|. Indeed, suppose |Œì‚Äã(Y)||Y|=|Œì‚Äã(X)||X|‚âúŒªŒìùëåùëåŒìùëãùëã‚âúùúÜ\frac{|\Gamma(Y)|}{|Y|}=\frac{|\Gamma(X)|}{|X|}\triangleq\lambda. By the submodularity of the cardinality of the neighborhood function of a graph,

|Œì‚Äã(X‚à™Y)|+|Œì‚Äã(X‚à©Y)|‚â§|Œì‚Äã(X)|+|Œì‚Äã(Y)|=Œª‚Äã(|X|+|Y|).ŒìùëãùëåŒìùëãùëåŒìùëãŒìùëåùúÜùëãùëå|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|+|\Gamma(X\cap Y)|\leq|\Gamma(X)|+|\Gamma(Y)|=\lambda(|X|+|Y|).

Notice that |Œì‚Äã(X‚à™Y)|‚â•Œª‚Äã|X‚à™Y|ŒìùëãùëåùúÜùëãùëå|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|\geq\lambda|X\cup Y| and |Œì‚Äã(X‚à©Y)|‚â•Œª‚Äã|X‚à©Y|ŒìùëãùëåùúÜùëãùëå|\Gamma(X\cap Y)|\geq\lambda|X\cap Y| by definition. If any of these two inequalities were strict we would have the contradiction

|Œì‚Äã(X‚à™Y)|+|Œì‚Äã(X‚à©Y)|>Œª‚Äã(|X‚à™Y|+|X‚à©Y|)=Œª‚Äã(|X|+|Y|).ŒìùëãùëåŒìùëãùëåùúÜùëãùëåùëãùëåùúÜùëãùëå|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|+|\Gamma(X\cap Y)|>\lambda(|X\cup Y|+|X\cap Y|)=\lambda(|X|+|Y|).

Hence the inequalities are not strict, and |Œì‚Äã(X‚à™Y)|=Œª‚Äã|X‚à™Y|ŒìùëãùëåùúÜùëãùëå|\Gamma(X\cup Y)|=\lambda|X\cup Y|. ‚àé

Along with Theorem¬†4.3, this observation suggests the following method, described in the FindBlocks method of Algorithm¬†2. By solving the LP in¬†(3) and using Lemma¬†3, we obtain a set XùëãX minimizing |Œì‚Äã(S)|/|S|ŒìùëÜùëÜ|\Gamma(S)|/|S|. Remove XùëãX from the graph Gùê∫G and repeat (if Gùê∫G is non-empty); let YùëåY be the new set obtained. If Œì‚Äã(Y)/|Y|=Œì‚Äã(X)/|X|ŒìùëåùëåŒìùëãùëã\Gamma(Y)/|Y|=\Gamma(X)/|X|, then replace XùëãX with X‚Ä≤=X‚à™Ysuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤ùëãùëåX^{\prime}=X\cup Y and repeat the process of finding a minimizer YùëåY via LP¬†(3); this strictly increases the size of XùëãX. Eventually we will obtain a YùëåY satisfying |Œì‚Äã(Y)|/|Y|>Œì‚Äã(X)/|X|ŒìùëåùëåŒìùëãùëã|\Gamma(Y)|/|Y|>\Gamma(X)/|X|, at which point we know that XùëãX is the maximal set minimizing Œì‚Äã(S)/|S|ŒìùëÜùëÜ\Gamma(S)/|S|, i.e., the first non-trivial block B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1} is XùëãX. Now remove B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1} and Œì‚Äã(B1)Œìsubscriptùêµ1\Gamma(B_{1}) from Gùê∫G and repeat (if applicable) to obtain B2,‚Ä¶,Bksubscriptùêµ2‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëòB_{2},\ldots,B_{k}.

Step 2: Obtaining a fair distribution for each block. The idea of this step is first to calculate the assignment probabilities xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} for all u‚ààL,v‚ààRformulae-sequenceùë¢ùêøùë£ùëÖu\in L,v\in R, i.e., the probability that uùë¢u is matched to vùë£v in some fixed maxmin-fair distribution FùêπF. As of yet these probabilities are unknown (and, unlike satisfaction probabilities, they need not be the same for all maxmin-fair distributions). However, we do know some conditions that they must satisfy because we know (from Theorem¬†4.3) the satisfaction probabilities of the left vertices in FùêπF, and all the right vertices need to be matched with probability 1 under our assumption that œÅ‚Äã(L)=|R|ùúåùêøùëÖ\rho(L)=|R|. These conditions may be expressed as linear constraints in xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv}, so we will find suitable values for xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} via a linear program. Finally we can turn these values into an actual distribution of matchings via the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition. Details follow.

Consider the graph Hi=G/‚ãÉj‚â§iBjsubscriptùêªùëñùê∫subscriptùëóùëñsubscriptùêµùëóH_{i}=G/\bigcup_{j\leq i}B_{j} obtained by removing all lower blocks and their neighbors. To simplify notation, rename L‚à©V‚Äã(Hi)ùêøùëâsubscriptùêªùëñL\cap V(H_{i}) and R‚à©V‚Äã(Hi)ùëÖùëâsubscriptùêªùëñR\cap V(H_{i}) to LùêøL and RùëÖR. We have |R|‚â§|L|ùëÖùêø|R|\leq|L| and Œª=|R|/|L|‚â§1ùúÜùëÖùêø1\lambda=|R|/|L|\leq 1. First we calculate the (as of yet unknown) probabilities xi‚Äãjsubscriptùë•ùëñùëóx_{ij} (i‚ààL,j‚ààRformulae-sequenceùëñùêøùëóùëÖi\in L,j\in R) that each edge (i,j)ùëñùëó(i,j) is saturated (i.e., iùëñi is matched to jùëój) in some fixed maxmin-fair distribution. Clearly ‚àëjxi‚Äãj=Œªsubscriptùëósubscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúÜ\sum_{j}x_{ij}=\lambda for each iùëñi and ‚àëixi‚Äãj=1subscriptùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëó1\sum_{i}x_{ij}=1 for each jùëój. Let us add a set ZùëçZ of |L|‚àí|R|ùêøùëÖ|L|-|R| fictitious vertices to RùëÖR and extend the domain of definition of xi‚Äãjsubscriptùë•ùëñùëóx_{ij} so as to satisfy xi‚Äãj=1/|L|subscriptùë•ùëñùëó1ùêøx_{ij}=1/|L| for each i‚ààL,j‚ààZformulae-sequenceùëñùêøùëóùëçi\in L,j\in Z. We obtain a bipartite graph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with |L|ùêø|L| vertices on each side; let Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} denote its neighborhood function. Then ‚àëv‚ààŒì‚Ä≤‚Äã(u)xu‚Äãv=1‚Äã‚àÄu‚ààL,‚àëu‚ààŒì‚Ä≤‚Äã(v)xu‚Äãv=1‚Äã‚àÄv‚ààR‚à™Z,and¬†‚Äãxu‚Äãv‚â•0‚Äã‚àÄu‚ààL,v‚ààR‚à™Z.formulae-sequencesubscriptùë£superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùë¢subscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£1for-allùë¢ùêøsubscriptùë¢superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùë£subscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£1for-allùë£ùëÖùëçand¬†subscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£0for-allùë¢ùêøùë£ùëÖùëç\sum_{v\in\Gamma^{\prime}(u)}x_{uv}=1\;\forall u\in L,\;\sum_{u\in\Gamma^{\prime}(v)}x_{uv}=1\;\forall v\in R\cup Z,\;\text{and }x_{uv}\geq 0\;\forall u\in L,v\in R\cup Z. We can find a solution xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} to these inequalities by solving a linear program.

By the following consequence of Birkhoff-von Neumann theorem on doubly stochastic matrices¬†birkhoff the quantities xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} thus obtained represent the edge saturation probabilities of an actual distribution of matchings in¬†G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime}:

Lemma 5 ().

Let {xu‚Äãv}(u,v)‚ààEsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£ùë¢ùë£ùê∏\{x_{uv}\}_{(u,v)\in E} be non-negative numbers s.t. ‚àëv‚ààRxu‚Äãv‚â§1‚Äã‚àÄu‚ààLsubscriptùë£ùëÖsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£1for-allùë¢ùêø\sum_{v\in R}x_{uv}\leq 1\;\forall u\in L and ‚àëu‚ààLxu‚Äãv‚â§1‚Äã‚àÄv‚ààRsubscriptùë¢ùêøsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£1for-allùë£ùëÖ\sum_{u\in L}x_{uv}\leq 1\;\forall v\in R. Then a distribution over |E|+1ùê∏1|E|+1 matchings such that PrM‚àà‚Ñ≥‚Å°[(u,v)‚ààM]=xu‚ÄãvsubscriptPrùëÄ‚Ñ≥ùë¢ùë£ùëÄsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£\Pr_{M\in{\mathcal{M}}}[(u,v)\in M]=x_{uv} exists and may be found in polynomial time.

We thus obtain a distribution Dùê∑D of matchings in G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} in which each edge (u,v)ùë¢ùë£(u,v) is used with probability¬†xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv}. If we pick each matching with its probability in Dùê∑D and remove from it the edges incident to the ‚Äùfictitious‚Äú elements in¬†ZùëçZ, we obtain a distribution of matchings where each element iùëñi of LùêøL is matched with probability 1‚àí‚àëj‚ààZxi‚Äãj=1‚àí(|Z|/|L|)=1‚àí(|L|‚àí|R|)/|L|=Œª1subscriptùëóùëçsubscriptùë•ùëñùëó1ùëçùêø1ùêøùëÖùêøùúÜ1-\sum_{j\in Z}x_{ij}=1-(|Z|/|L|)=1-(|L|-|R|)/|L|=\lambda, as desired.

Step 3: Combining the distributions. The last step requires combining the distributions D1,‚Ä¶,Dksubscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëòD_{1},\ldots,D_{k}, each defined for a block BisubscriptùêµùëñB_{i}, into a single maxmin-fair distribution for Gùê∫G. The simplest way is to draw (M1,‚Ä¶,Mk)subscriptùëÄ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÄùëò(M_{1},\ldots,M_{k}) from the product distribution D1√óD2‚Äã‚Ä¶√óDksubscriptùê∑1subscriptùê∑2‚Ä¶subscriptùê∑ùëòD_{1}\times D_{2}\ldots\times D_{k} and return M1‚à™M2‚Äã‚Ä¶‚à™MksubscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëÄùëòM_{1}\cup M_{2}\ldots\cup M_{k}. (This is an easily samplable maxmin-fair distribution with potentially large support.)

Putting all together, we obtain the following.

Theorem 4.4.

Algorithm¬†2 is a polynomial-time algorithm for the one-sided maxmin-fair matching problem.

5 A more efficient algorithm

The algorithm from Section¬†4 requires solving polynomially many LP subproblems. It was presented to showcase the main steps required, to introduce the fair decompositions, and to establish the existence of a polynomial-time algorithm. In this section we analyze a more efficient algorithm. It also follows each of the three steps outlined in Algorithm¬†1, but differs from Algorithm¬†2 in two key respects:

  • ‚Ä¢

    For step 1, it finds fairly separated sets in arbitrary order, rather than bottom-up. These sets can be found by maximum flow computations in a certain graph, and a single flow computation can be used to find many new blocks in the decomposition simultaneously.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For step 2, it uses a fast edge-coloring algorithm on a carefully constructed regular bipartite graph, allowing us to bypass the (comparatively slow) Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition (for which the best known algorithm from¬†perfect_nlogn runs in œâ‚Äã(|V|‚Äã|E|)ùúîùëâùê∏\omega(|V||E|) time).

We present pseudocode for the improved algorithm (Algorithm¬†3) at the end of this section. We establish the following:

Theorem 5.1 ().

Algorithm¬†3 solves the maxmin-fair one-sided bipartite matching problem in O‚Äã((|V|2+|E|‚Äã|V|2/3)‚ãÖ(log‚Å°|V|)2)ùëÇ‚ãÖsuperscriptùëâ2ùê∏superscriptùëâ23superscriptùëâ2O((|V|^{2}+|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) expected time.

5.1 Improved step 1: Finding a fair decomposition

Suppose we wish to separate LùêøL into vertices with satisfaction probability <ŒªabsentùúÜ<\lambda and vertices with satisfaction probability ‚â•ŒªabsentùúÜ\geq\lambda, for some parameter Œª‚àà(0,1)ùúÜ01\lambda\in(0,1). To perform this check, construct the graph G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda) by adding to Gùê∫G a source vertex sùë†s connected to every u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L with an edge of capacity ŒªùúÜ\lambda, and a sink vertex tùë°t connected to every v‚ààRùë£ùëÖv\in R with an edge of capacity 1; all other edges have infinite capacity.

Lemma 6.

Let Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa be the value of a minimum s‚àítùë†ùë°s-t cut in G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda). Then exactly one of the following cases holds: (a) Œ∫=Œª‚Äã|L|ùúÖùúÜùêø\kappa=\lambda|L| and œÄ‚Äã(G)‚â•Œªùúãùê∫ùúÜ\pi(G)\geq\lambda; or (b) Œ∫<Œª‚Äã|L|ùúÖùúÜùêø\kappa<\lambda|L| and there is a fairly-isolated subset X‚ääLùëãùêøX\subsetneq L such that Œ†‚Äã(G|X)<ŒªŒ†|ùê∫ùëãùúÜ\Pi(G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{X}}$}})<\lambda. ‚ÄÑ We can determine which case occurs, and obtain XùëãX in case (b), with a min-cut computation on G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda).

Recall that œÄ‚Äã(G)ùúãùê∫\pi(G) (resp., Œ†‚Äã(G)Œ†ùê∫\Pi(G)) represents the minimum (resp., maximum) satisfaction probabilities in a maxmin-fair distribution for Gùê∫G. In either of the two cases contemplated by Lemma¬†6 we have ‚Äúmade progress‚Äù by solving a min-cut problem on G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda); either (a) we showed that achieving minimum satisfaction probability ŒªùúÜ\lambda is possible, or (b) found a fair separation (and a reason why it is not possible).

Proof.

Consider a minimum-value s‚àítùë†ùë°s-t cut in G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda). Because the capacities of the edges from sùë†s are no larger than any other capacity, there is always a cut Cùê∂C with no larger value containing no edges from LùêøL to RùëÖR. Cùê∂C only contains edges from sùë†s to some subset A¬ØL‚äÜLsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøùêø\overline{A}_{L}\subseteq L and from some subset AR‚ààRsubscriptùê¥ùëÖùëÖA_{R}\in R to tùë°t; its value is Œª‚Äã|A¬ØL|+|AR|ùúÜsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøsubscriptùê¥ùëÖ\lambda|\overline{A}_{L}|+|A_{R}|.

Let AL=L‚àñA¬ØLsubscriptùê¥ùêøùêøsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøA_{L}=L\setminus\overline{A}_{L} and A¬ØR=R‚àñARsubscript¬Øùê¥ùëÖùëÖsubscriptùê¥ùëÖ\overline{A}_{R}=R\setminus A_{R}. Because Cùê∂C is an s,tùë†ùë°s,t-cut, there are no edges in Gùê∫G (or in G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda)) between ALsubscriptùê¥ùêøA_{L} and A¬ØRsubscript¬Øùê¥ùëÖ\overline{A}_{R}, so Œì‚Äã(AL)‚äÜARŒìsubscriptùê¥ùêøsubscriptùê¥ùëÖ\Gamma(A_{L})\subseteq A_{R}. As Cùê∂C is a minimum cut, we must in fact have Œì‚Äã(AL)=ARŒìsubscriptùê¥ùêøsubscriptùê¥ùëÖ\Gamma(A_{L})=A_{R} (or else cutting some edges from ARsubscriptùê¥ùëÖA_{R} to tùë°t is unnecessary). The value of Cùê∂C is Œª‚Äã|A¬ØL|+|AR|ùúÜsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøsubscriptùê¥ùëÖ\lambda|\overline{A}_{L}|+|A_{R}|. Furthermore, for any X‚äÜA¬ØLùëãsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøX\subseteq\overline{A}_{L} we must have |Œì‚Äã(X)‚àñŒì‚Äã(AL)|‚â•Œª‚Äã|X|ŒìùëãŒìsubscriptùê¥ùêøùúÜùëã|\Gamma(X)\setminus\Gamma(A_{L})|\geq\lambda|X|, for otherwise there would be a cut of smaller value

Œª‚Äã|A¬ØL‚àñX|+|Œì‚Äã(AL‚à™X)|=(Œª‚Äã|A¬ØL|+|AR|)‚àíŒª‚Äã|X|+|Œì‚Äã(X)‚àñAR|.ùúÜsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøùëãŒìsubscriptùê¥ùêøùëãùúÜsubscript¬Øùê¥ùêøsubscriptùê¥ùëÖùúÜùëãŒìùëãsubscriptùê¥ùëÖ\lambda|\overline{A}_{L}\setminus X|+|\Gamma(A_{L}\cup X)|=(\lambda|\overline{A}_{L}|+|A_{R}|)-\lambda|X|+|\Gamma(X)\setminus A_{R}|.

So the fairness parameter œÄ‚Äã(G/AL)ùúãùê∫subscriptùê¥ùêø\pi(G/{A_{L}}) is at least ŒªùúÜ\lambda. If AL=‚àÖsubscriptùê¥ùêøA_{L}=\emptyset, this is œÄ‚Äã(G)ùúãùê∫\pi(G) and we are in case (a) of the Lemma.

If AL‚â†‚àÖsubscriptùê¥ùêøA_{L}\neq\emptyset, let C=C‚Äã(Œª)ùê∂ùê∂ùúÜC=C(\lambda) be the minimum cut with minimum |AL|subscriptùê¥ùêø|A_{L}|. Then ALsubscriptùê¥ùêøA_{L} is unique and may be determined in linear time by picking the vertices reachable from sùë†s in the residual network of a maximum (pre)flow¬†all_mincuts . For any Y‚äÜALùëåsubscriptùê¥ùêøY\subseteq A_{L}, we must have |Œì‚Äã(AL)|‚àí|Œì‚Äã(AL‚àñY)|<Œª‚Äã|Y|Œìsubscriptùê¥ùêøŒìsubscriptùê¥ùêøùëåùúÜùëå|\Gamma(A_{L})|-|\Gamma(A_{L}\setminus Y)|<\lambda|Y|, otherwise another cut C‚Ä≤superscriptùê∂‚Ä≤C^{\prime} of at most the same same value but with |AL‚Ä≤|<|AL|subscriptsuperscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùêøsubscriptùê¥ùêø|A^{\prime}_{L}|<|A_{L}| would exist. Hence Œ†‚Äã(G|AL)<ŒªŒ†|ùê∫subscriptùê¥ùêøùúÜ\Pi(G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{A_{L}}}$}})<\lambda by Corollary¬†3 which, along with the previously derived inequality œÄ‚Äã(G/AL)‚â•Œªùúãùê∫subscriptùê¥ùêøùúÜ\pi(G/{A_{L}})\geq\lambda, states that ALsubscriptùê¥ùêøA_{L} is a fairly separated set, and we are in case (b). ‚àé

The parametric flow algorithm of Gallo et al¬†parametric_flow can find the cuts C‚Äã(Œª)ùê∂ùúÜC(\lambda) in the proof of Lemma¬†6 simultaneously for all ŒªùúÜ\lambda (in the sense of giving a cut for all possible |L|‚àí1ùêø1|L|-1 ‚Äúbreakpoints‚Äù for ŒªùúÜ\lambda). Its running time is asymptotically the same time as that of a single maximum-flow computation via the push-relabel algorithm of¬†push_relabel . However, this technique does not extend to all max-flow algorithms, and¬†push_relabel is suboptimal for the graphs G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda). A better idea is the following (see Algorithm¬†3).

Start with Œª=1ùúÜ1\lambda=1 and keep halving ŒªùúÜ\lambda as long as case (a) holds in Lemma¬†6. The first time that (b) occurs we have found a fairly separated set XùëãX. At this point we can find recursively the blocks in the fair decompositions of G|X|ùê∫ùëãG{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{X}}$}} and G/Xùê∫ùëãG/X. The crucial insight is that we can find both in a single recursive call: G|X|ùê∫ùëãG{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{X}}$}} and G/Xùê∫ùëãG/X are disjoint, so min-cuts for (G|X)‚Äã(Œª1)|ùê∫ùëãsubscriptùúÜ1(G{{\mathbin{|}}\raise-3.87495pt\hbox{${\scriptstyle{X}}$}})(\lambda_{1}) and (G/X)‚Äã(Œª2)ùê∫ùëãsubscriptùúÜ2(G/X)(\lambda_{2}) are easily obtained from min-cuts for a single graph G‚Äã(Œª1,Œª2;X,X¬Ø)ùê∫subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2ùëã¬ØùëãG(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2};X,\overline{X}) containing a disjoint copy of each (except that we still keep a single source sùë†s and a single sink tùë°t).

An iterative implementation of this idea maintainins the following invariant:

  1. (a)

    we keep a partition of LùêøL into t‚â§kùë°ùëòt\leq k subsets T1,‚Ä¶,Ttsubscriptùëá1‚Ä¶subscriptùëáùë°T_{1},\ldots,T_{t};

  2. (b)

    each TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i} is the union of consecutive blocks in the decomposition (in other words, it is the difference between two fairly isolated sets);

  3. (c)

    we have computed lower and upper bounds ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} and Œºisubscriptùúáùëñ\mu_{i} for the maxmin-fair probabilities of vertices in TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i}, i.e., [œÄ‚Äã(Ti),Œ†‚Äã(Ti)]‚äÜ[Œªi,Œºi)ùúãsubscriptùëáùëñŒ†subscriptùëáùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùúáùëñ[\pi(T_{i}),\Pi(T_{i})]\subseteq[\lambda_{i},\mu_{i});

  4. (d)

    these bounds satisfy Œºi‚àíŒªi=2‚àíjsubscriptùúáùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscript2ùëó\mu_{i}-\lambda_{i}=2^{-j} at iteration j‚â•0ùëó0j\geq 0.

Initially, t=1ùë°1t=1, T1=Lsubscriptùëá1ùêøT_{1}=L, Œª1=0subscriptùúÜ10\lambda_{1}=0, Œº1=1subscriptùúá11\mu_{1}=1 (valid by the assumption œÅ‚Äã(L)<|L|ùúåùêøùêø\rho(L)<|L|), and j=0ùëó0j=0. Construct the graph G‚Äã(Œª1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,Œªt‚Ä≤;T1,‚Ä¶,Tt)ùê∫superscriptsubscriptùúÜ1‚Ä≤‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúÜùë°‚Ä≤subscriptùëá1‚Ä¶subscriptùëáùë°G(\lambda_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,\lambda_{t}^{\prime};T_{1},\ldots,T_{t}) where the edge capacities from sùë†s to each u‚ààTiùë¢subscriptùëáùëñu\in T_{i} are Œªi‚Ä≤=(Œªi+Œºi)/2superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùúáùëñ2\lambda_{i}^{\prime}=(\lambda_{i}+\mu_{i})/2, and edges from u‚ààTiùë¢subscriptùëáùëñu\in T_{i} to v‚ààŒì‚Äã(Tj)ùë£Œìsubscriptùëáùëóv\in\Gamma(T_{j}) where j‚â†iùëóùëñj\neq i are deleted. With a min-cut computation in G‚Äã(Œª1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,Œªt‚Ä≤;T1,‚Ä¶,Tt)ùê∫superscriptsubscriptùúÜ1‚Ä≤‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúÜùë°‚Ä≤subscriptùëá1‚Ä¶subscriptùëáùë°G(\lambda_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,\lambda_{t}^{\prime};T_{1},\ldots,T_{t}) we reduce the range of parameter bounds within TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i} by half for each iùëñi, and possibly split TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i} into two (increasing tùë°t) if we found a new fairly separated set. After the min-cut computation, obtaining the new partition of LùêøL, the new upper bounds, and removing the edges from lower blocks to higher ones takes linear time.

After O‚Äã(log‚Å°|L|)ùëÇùêøO(\log|L|) iterations (each performing a min-cut and a linear-time update), we have Œºi‚àíŒªi<1/|L|2subscriptùúáùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñ1superscriptùêø2\mu_{i}-\lambda_{i}<1/|L|^{2} for all iùëñi, at which point we have determined the full decomposition (because each maxmin-fair satisfaction probability is of the form a/bùëéùëèa/b where a‚â§b,1‚â§b‚â§|L|formulae-sequenceùëéùëè1ùëèùêøa\leq b,1\leq b\leq|L|). The running time of the max-flow algorithm of¬†flow_unit for bipartite networks with rational capacities with denominators bounded by a polynomial in |V|ùëâ|V| is O‚Äã(min‚Å°(|E|3/2,|E|‚Äã|V|2/3)‚ãÖlog‚Å°|V|)ùëÇ‚ãÖsuperscriptùê∏32ùê∏superscriptùëâ23ùëâO(\min(|E|^{3/2},|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot\log|V|). We obtain:

Theorem 5.2.

The fair decomposition of a graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) for the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem can be found in time O‚Äã(min‚Å°(|E|3/2,|E|‚Äã|V|2/3)‚ãÖ(log‚Å°|V|)2)ùëÇ‚ãÖsuperscriptùê∏32ùê∏superscriptùëâ23superscriptùëâ2O(\min(|E|^{3/2},|E||V|^{2/3})\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}).

5.2 Improved step 2: Obtaining a fair distribution for each block

Here we describe the procedure in Algorithm¬†3 to find fair distributions once the fair decomposition has been computed. As before, suppose that Gùê∫G itself has a single block, so Œì‚Äã(L)=Œª‚Äã|R|ŒìùêøùúÜùëÖ\Gamma(L)=\lambda|R|. Let g=gcd‚Å°(|L|,|R|)ùëîùêøùëÖg=\gcd(|L|,|R|) and l=|L|/gùëôùêøùëîl=|L|/g, r=|R|/gùëüùëÖùëîr=|R|/g.

Let G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda) be as in Lemma¬†6. By the max-flow/min-cut theorem, there is a flow in G‚Äã(Œª)ùê∫ùúÜG(\lambda) with of value Œª‚Äã|L|=|R|ùúÜùêøùëÖ\lambda|L|=|R|. Since the incoming edges to any u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L from sùë†s have capacity ŒªùúÜ\lambda, the flow from sùë†s to vùë£v must be precisely ŒªùúÜ\lambda. Let xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} be flow between u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L and v‚ààRùë£ùëÖv\in R. Then ‚àëu‚ààLxu‚Äãv=Œª=lrsubscriptùë¢ùêøsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£ùúÜùëôùëü\sum_{u\in L}x_{uv}=\lambda=\frac{l}{r} and ‚àëv‚ààRxu‚Äãv=1subscriptùë£ùëÖsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£1\sum_{v\in R}x_{uv}=1, so we found the edge saturation probabilities {xu‚Äãv}subscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£\{x_{uv}\} of a maxmin-fair distribution.

Consider now the subgraph G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} of Gùê∫G containing only those edges for which xu‚Äãv>0subscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£0x_{uv}>0. By Lemma¬†5, the same edge probabilities xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} warrant the existence of a distribution of matchings in G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} with satisfaction probability ŒªùúÜ\lambda.

By the integral flow theorem¬†lawler_book , each xu‚Äãvsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£x_{uv} may be assumed to be a multiple of 1/r1ùëü1/r, because all capacities in G‚Ä≤superscriptùê∫‚Ä≤G^{\prime} are multiples of 1/r1ùëü1/r; in fact any standard maximum-flow algorithm returns such a solution. Now consider the (r,l)ùëüùëô(r,l)-biregular multigraph PùëÉP obtained by putting nu‚Äãv=xu‚Äãv‚ãÖrsubscriptùëõùë¢ùë£‚ãÖsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£ùëün_{uv}=x_{uv}\cdot r parallel edges between u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L and v‚ààRùë£ùëÖv\in R. As in step 2 of Sec.¬†4.5, we add to the right side of PùëÉP a set ZùëçZ of |L‚àñR|ùêøùëÖ|L\setminus R| vertices. Joining the iùëñith vertex of LùêøL with the jùëójth vertex of ZùëçZ whenever i‚â°jmodgùëñmoduloùëóùëîi\equiv j\bmod g, we obtain from PùëÉP a graph P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime} which is bipartite and lùëôl-regular.

Any bipartite graph of maximum degree lùëôl is lùëôl-edge-colorable so that no two adjacent edges share a color by K≈ënig‚Äôs theorem (see¬†matching_book ). Each color class is a matching, so there are lùëôl matchings in P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime} covering each u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L exactly lùëôl times in total. Cole et al¬†edge_coloring give an algorithm to color regular bipartite graphs in time O‚Äã(m‚Äãlog‚Å°r)=O‚Äã(m‚Äãlog‚Å°|Œì‚Äã(L)|)ùëÇùëöùëüùëÇùëöŒìùêøO(m\log r)=O(m\log|\Gamma(L)|), where mùëöm is the number of edges of P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime}; in our case m=O‚Äã(l‚ãÖ|E‚Äã(G)|)ùëöùëÇ‚ãÖùëôùê∏ùê∫m=O(l\cdot|E(G)|). Goel et al¬†perfect_nlogn give a randomized algorithm to color lùëôl-regular bipartite graphs in expected time O‚Äã(l‚Äãn2‚Äãlog2‚Å°(n))ùëÇùëôsuperscriptùëõ2superscript2ùëõO(ln^{2}\log^{2}(n)), where nùëõn is the number of vertices of P‚Ä≤superscriptùëÉ‚Ä≤P^{\prime}; in our case n=O‚Äã(|L|)ùëõùëÇùêøn=O(|L|) and we can use the crude bound l‚â§|L|ùëôùêøl\leq|L|, so it runs in O‚Äã(|L|2‚Äãlog2‚Å°(|L|))ùëÇsuperscriptùêø2superscript2ùêøO(|L|^{2}\log^{2}(|L|)). If we remove the ‚Äúfictitious‚Äù vertices in ZùëçZ from each of these matchings, we are left with a multiset of lùëôl matchings in Gùê∫G covering each u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L exactly rùëür times. The uniform distribution over them is thus maxmin-fair for Gùê∫G.

Now consider the case that the decomposition of Gùê∫G has several blocks B1,‚Ä¶,Bksubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëòB_{1},\ldots,B_{k}. The values xu‚Äãvisuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùë¢ùë£ùëñx_{uv}^{i} for all blocks iùëñi can be computed from a single maximum-flow computation in G‚Äã(Œª1,‚Ä¶,Œªk;B1,‚Ä¶,Bk)ùê∫subscriptùúÜ1‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜùëòsubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëòG(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{k};B_{1},\ldots,B_{k}) if we know the blocks and each satisfaction probability ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i}. Then each corresponding coloring can be found in time O‚Äã(ni2‚Äãlog2‚Å°(ni))ùëÇsuperscriptsubscriptùëõùëñ2superscript2subscriptùëõùëñO(n_{i}^{2}\log^{2}(n_{i})); summing these running times and noticing that ‚àëini2‚â§|L|2subscriptùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëõùëñ2superscriptùêø2\sum_{i}n_{i}^{2}\leq|L|^{2}, we deduce:

Theorem 5.3.

Given the fair decomposition, a maxmin-fair distribution for all blocks in it can be found in O‚Äã(|V|2‚ãÖ(log‚Å°|V|)2)ùëÇ‚ãÖsuperscriptùëâ2superscriptùëâ2O(|V|^{2}\cdot(\log|V|)^{2}) expected time and O‚Äã(|V|‚Äã|E|‚Äãlog‚Å°|V|)ùëÇùëâùê∏ùëâO(|V||E|\log|V|) deterministic time after a max-flow computation.

Putting all together yields Theorem¬†5.1.

6 Generalization to non-bipartite graphs

Recall that so far we have concerned ourselves with the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem, i.e., the special case of fair matching where Gùê∫G is bipartite (with bipartition V=L‚Äã‚à™Àô‚ÄãRùëâùêøÀôùëÖV=L\ \dot{\cup}\ R) and the set of users is ùí∞=Lùí∞ùêø{\mathcal{U}}=L.

Notably, this special case can encode any other matching problem, and moreover we can make the simplifying assumption that LùêøL is matchable and larger than RùëÖR. To show this, we make use of the following result from transversal theory.

Theorem 6.1 (Ford and Fulkerson¬†transversals ).

For any graph Gùê∫G there exists a bipartite graph HùêªH with bipartition (LH,RH)subscriptùêøùêªsubscriptùëÖùêª(L_{H},R_{H}) such that LH=V‚Äã(G)subscriptùêøùêªùëâùê∫L_{H}=V(G) and the collection of matchable subsets of V‚Äã(G)ùëâùê∫V(G) in Gùê∫G equals the collection of matchable subsets of LHsubscriptùêøùêªL_{H} in HùêªH.

This is normally stated as ‚Äúany matching matroid is transversal‚Äù. The construction of HùêªH in Theorem¬†6.1 can be carried out in polynomial time (see¬†transversals_short for a simple proof). Hence the case of non-bipartite Gùê∫G can be reduced to the one-sided bipartite case. A similar remark applies to general user sets ùí∞‚äÜVùí∞ùëâ{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V, as we can remove from LHsubscriptùêøùêªL_{H} the elements of V‚àñùí∞ùëâùí∞V\setminus{\mathcal{U}}, which has no effect on the collection of matchable subsets of ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}} in HùêªH.

We make the additional simplifying assumption that RùëÖR is matchable. If not, find an arbitrary maximum matching of Gùê∫G and remove from RùëÖR all unmatched vertices. Let R‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤R^{\prime} denote the remaining vertices.

Theorem 6.2 (Mendelsohn and Dulmage¬†mendelson_dulmage ).

If both A‚äÜLùê¥ùêøA\subseteq L and B‚äÜRùêµùëÖB\subseteq R are matchable in a bipartite graph Gùê∫G with bipartition (L,R)ùêøùëÖ(L,R), then A‚à™Bùê¥ùêµA\cup B is also matchable in Gùê∫G.

It follows that for each distribution of matchings of Gùê∫G there is another distribution with the same coverage (satisfaction) probabilities for LùêøL and covering only elements of L‚à™R‚Ä≤ùêøsuperscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤L\cup R^{\prime}. Note that the coverage probability of each v‚ààR‚Ä≤ùë£superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤v\in R^{\prime} in this distribution is 1. The case where œÅ‚Äã(L)=|R|ùúåùêøùëÖ\rho(L)=|R| is easily handled separately (any maximum matching algorithm is maxmin-fair in this case), yielding the following (see Appendix¬†B for details):

Theorem 6.3 ().

The fair matching problem on arbitrary graphs with arbitrary user sets ùí∞‚äÜVùí∞ùëâ{\mathcal{U}}\subseteq V can be reduced in polynomial time to the one-sided fair bipartite matching problem on graphs where œÅ‚Äã(L)=|R|<|L|ùúåùêøùëÖùêø\rho(L)=|R|<|L|.

Proof.

Let ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} be a maxmin-fair algorithm for one-sided bipartite matching problem described. Given a graph Gùê∫G and a user set ùí∞ùí∞{\mathcal{U}}, we

  1. (1)

    construct HùêªH as in Theorem¬†6.1;

  2. (2)

    remove from LHsubscriptùêøùêªL_{H} the elements of V‚Äã(G)‚àñùí∞ùëâùê∫ùí∞V(G)\setminus{\mathcal{U}};

  3. (3)

    find an arbitrary maximum matching MùëÄM and remove from RHsubscriptùëÖùêªR_{H} the elements not covered by MùëÄM, using any polynomial-time maximum matching algorithm.

  4. (4)

    find a fair one-sided bipartite matching by either (a) using ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} on the resulting graph if |M|<|LH|ùëÄsubscriptùêøùêª|M|<|L_{H}| or (b) returning MùëÄM if |M|=|LH|ùëÄsubscriptùêøùêª|M|=|L_{H}|;

  5. (5)

    given the solution SùëÜS found at the previous step, return a matching in Gùê∫G covering the same vertices as SùëÜS using an explicit algorithm for Berge‚Äôs theorem¬†edmonds_algo .

(Step (5) is technically redundant as we identify solutions with sets of matchable users, but is included for clarity.)

It is plain to see that the resulting distribution is maxmin-fair for the general problem if and only if ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} is maxmin-fair for the one-sided problem. All steps run in polynomial time, possibly excluding the call to ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} itself. ‚àé

Combining Theorems¬†5.1 and¬†6.3, we obtain the following.

Theorem 6.4.

The maxmin-fair matching problem on general unweighted graphs is solvable in polynomial time.

7 On transparency and practical deployment

Even a provably fair algorithm might still be perceived by the average user as a blackbox outputting an arbitrary solution. For the sake of transparency and accountability, it can be interesting to publish all the solutions in a maxmin-fair distribution (along with their respective probabilities). Once a complete fair distribution is published, convincing any user uùë¢u of fair treatment amounts to:

  1. (1)

    letting uùë¢u verify independently the fairness guarantees of the distribution (for this it is also possible to output a short certificate, based on the fair decomposition, of the fact that no higher probability for uùë¢u is possible in a maxmin-fair distribution); and

  2. (2)

    picking one of the published solutions at random, via any fair and transparent lottery mechanism or coin-tossing protocol (this is the only stage where randomness plays a role, as the distribution of matchings itself can be found deterministically).

One difficulty is the potentially large support size of the maxmin-fair distribution, which could prevent publication. An interesting question is if we can produce a maxmin-fair distribution with small support. It turns out that for matchings, |L|‚àí1ùêø1|L|-1 solutions always suffice; although the actual number can be substantially smaller in practice (as shown in Section¬†8).

Let us discuss how to modify our algorithm so as to find a maxmin-fair distribution FùêπF using at most |L|+1‚àíkùêø1ùëò|L|+1-k matchings, where kùëòk is the number of non-trivial blocks in Theorem¬†4.3. (This could replace step 3 of Algorithm¬†1.) When k=1ùëò1k=1, the technique from step 2 of Algorithm¬†3 gives a multiset of l‚â§|L|ùëôùêøl\leq|L| matchings.

Consider the case k=2ùëò2k=2, which implies our claim for larger kùëòk by induction. Suppose Dùê∑D (resp., D‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤D^{\prime}) chooses matching Mi,i‚àà[r]subscriptùëÄùëñùëñdelimited-[]ùëüM_{i},i\in[r] on B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1} (resp., Nj,j‚àà[t]subscriptùëÅùëóùëódelimited-[]ùë°N_{j},j\in[t] on B2subscriptùêµ2B_{2}) with probability pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} (resp., qjsubscriptùëûùëóq_{j}). (Here B1‚à©B2=‚àÖsubscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2B_{1}\cap B_{2}=\emptyset.) A simple greedy algorithm can construct a distribution ZùëçZ of matchings in B1‚à™B2subscriptùêµ1subscriptùêµ2B_{1}\cup B_{2} such that D‚Äã[u]=Z‚Äã[u]ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢ùëçdelimited-[]ùë¢{D}[{u}]={Z}[{u}] for u‚ààB1ùë¢subscriptùêµ1u\in B_{1} and D‚Ä≤‚Äã[u]=Z‚Äã[u]superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùë¢ùëçdelimited-[]ùë¢{D^{\prime}}[{u}]={Z}[{u}] for u‚ààB2ùë¢subscriptùêµ2u\in B_{2} with at most r+t‚àí1ùëüùë°1r+t-1 matchings, as follows.

Keep indices i‚àà[r]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëüi\in[r], j‚àà[t]ùëódelimited-[]ùë°j\in[t] and let SùëÜS denote a set of (probability, matching) pairs, which will define the desired distribution at the end. At the outset S=‚àÖùëÜS=\emptyset and i=j=1ùëñùëó1i=j=1; at each iteration we add to SùëÜS the new pair (Œ¥,Mi‚à™Nj)ùõøsubscriptùëÄùëñsubscriptùëÅùëó(\delta,M_{i}\cup N_{j}) where Œ¥=min‚Å°(pi,qj)ùõøsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëûùëó\delta=\min(p_{i},q_{j}). We decrement pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} and qjsubscriptùëûùëóq_{j} by Œ¥ùõø\delta and increment iùëñi (resp., jùëój) if pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} (resp, qjsubscriptùëûùëóq_{j}) vanishes. The process terminates when iùëñi and jùëój reach the end of their range, at which point |S|=r+t‚àí1ùëÜùëüùë°1|S|=r+t-1 and all probabilities in SùëÜS sum up to 1.

We note, however, that this procedure may produce some matchings with very small probabilities, so the precision needed to specify a maxmin-fair distribution exactly will grow.

8 Experimental evaluation

We evaluate the practical performance of our fair matching algorithm by measuring its running time and its ability to scale to large graphs, and analyzing the distribution of maxmin-fair satisfaction probabilities and how they compare with those from two baselines. We also describe the features of the fair decompositions obtained.

Reproducibility. Our code is available at https://github.com/elhipercubo/maxmin_fair_bipartite_matching.git. It implements the improved algorithm from Sec.¬†5, with some implementation choices described below. It was compiled with g++ using -O3 optimizations and run on a dual-core Intel i7-7560U CPU (2.40 GHz) with 16Gb RAM.

Datasets. We used publicly-available bipartite graphs of various types, sizes and domains: all the graphs are already bipartite at the source repository, so that no preprocessing was needed. Table¬†2 reports their main characteristics.

Methods tested. We compare the following four methods to output maximum matchings:

(UF)

Unfair: A standard maximum matching algorithm using maximum flows, optimized for runtime using the techniques from¬†hipr . We use it for runtime comparisons only, because such a deterministic mechanism is inherently unfair as argued in Section¬†1.

(MF)

Maxmin fair: Our mechanism, using the improved algorithm from Sec.¬†5.

(PS)

Probabilistic Serial (from¬†pserial ): The goal here is to find a set of edge flows from LùêøL to RùëÖR which can be converted into a matching distribution by using the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition.

PS attempts to find a fair flow via a greedy algorithm, as follows: each user u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L sends flow at the same fixed rate, sharing this rate equally among her neighbours. When the outgoing flow of u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L (or the ingoing flow of v‚ààRùë£ùëÖv\in R) reaches 1, remove uùë¢u (or vùë£v). Repeat while there are edges remaining.

Unlike¬†MF, this mechanism is not Pareto-efficient (i.e., it does not necessarily return maximum matchings), but like¬†MF, a single run of the mechanism can be used to output all satisfaction probabilities.

(RP)

Random Priority (see¬†pserial ): It finds a matchable set of vertices as follows:

Let S=‚àÖùëÜS=\emptyset. Process all users in random order, adding user uùë¢u to SùëÜS if S‚à™{u}ùëÜùë¢S\cup\{u\} is matchable. Return a matching covering the final set SùëÜS.

Like¬†MF, this mechanism is Pareto-efficient, but unlike¬†MF, a single run of the mechanism only outputs a single matching and hence cannot be used to compute all satisfaction probabilities.

The latter two methods arose from work in economics in a different setting: randomized assignments on full bipartite graphs with ordinal preferences, i.e., where every u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L has a full ranking of all possible partners v‚ààRùë£ùëÖv\in R, and the goal is to design mechanisms which are ordinally efficient. (By contrast, in our setting the graph is not complete but there are no ordinal preferences: each user considers all of its neighbours equally desirable.) However they can be naturally applied in our context as well.

Implementation. We used the improved algorithm from Sec.¬†5. For max flow computations we chose the highest-label push-relabel algorithm of¬†push_relabel , which performs best with the gap heuristic from¬†eff_pushrelabel . We follow Goldberg techniques from¬†hipr : efficient gap detection is done via bucket lists of active nodes at each level¬†hipr , and we arrange edges from/to the same vertex consecutively to take advantage of cache locality. We avoid floating-point computations by using exact integral multipliers.

For reasons of simplicity and/or practical efficiency, our implementation departs from the pseudocode in Algorithm¬†3 in the points below. None of these changes affect correctness.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In FairDecomposition (line 8), only a pre-flow algorithm (the first phase of¬†push_relabel ) is run. This always suffices to find min-cuts (not max-flows) and thus fairly separated sets, and can halve the runtime.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In FairDecomposition (line 7), instead of setting Œªi‚Ä≤=(Œªi+Œºi)/2superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ‚Ä≤subscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùúáùëñ2\lambda_{i}^{\prime}=(\lambda_{i}+\mu_{i})/2 when building the graph G‚Äã(Œª1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,Œªt‚Ä≤;T1,‚Ä¶,Tt)ùê∫superscriptsubscriptùúÜ1‚Ä≤‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúÜùë°‚Ä≤subscriptùëá1‚Ä¶subscriptùëáùë°G(\lambda_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,\lambda_{t}^{\prime};T_{1},\ldots,T_{t}), we set it to |Œì‚Äã(Ti)|/|Ti|Œìsubscriptùëáùëñsubscriptùëáùëñ|\Gamma(T_{i})|/|T_{i}|. That is, our implementation guesses optimistically that TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i} is actually a single block in the decomposition, with the pre flow computation used to verify that guess or split the block in two. This also allows us to change the terminating condition (line 6) and stop earlier: rather than stopping when ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} and Œºisubscriptùúáùëñ\mu_{i} are very close, which may occur long after the full decomposition have been found, we stop when no block is split. This new choice for Œªi‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ‚Ä≤\lambda_{i}^{\prime} may invalidate our theoretical bound on the number of flow computations required, but it makes the code much faster in practice.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In SingleBlockDistribution (lines 27‚Äì32), we do not always build PùëÉP because PùëÉP may be quite large for some blocks with a small number of right vertices (where r‚â™lmuch-less-thanùëüùëôr\ll l), due to the fictitious edges added. Rather, we first attempt to find lùëôl disjoint matchings of size rùëür in arbitrary order without including fictitious vertices/edges. This often succeeds and, when it does, gives a correct coloring. When this fails, we build PùëÉP and proceed to find the coloring as described.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In SingleBlockDistribution (line 32), we do not use Goel et al‚Äôs edge coloring algorithm on PùëÉP. Rather, we find lùëôl matchings of size lùëôl one by one. This simplifies the implementation, but may impact performance and the runtime bound.

8.1 Fair decompositions: characteristics

Table¬†3 shows the number of blocks kùëòk in the fair decomposition (for informative purposes), the number of distinct edges e1subscriptùëí1e_{1} used in a maxmin-fair distribution FùêπF, the number of matchings MùëÄM in the support of FùêπF, and the time to compute the decomposition. As we anticipated in Section 7 the number of matchings needed for a fair distribution (MùëÄM) is in practice much smaller than |L|ùêø|L|. Another observation is that e1subscriptùëí1e_{1} exceeds |L|ùêø|L| only slightly. This is a measure of the storage needed to publish a summary containing the fair decomposition, the satisfaction probabilities, and the probability of each edge being used in the matching, which can be verified independently. (Publishing an explicit list of MùëÄM matchings of size œÅùúå\rho explicitly would take much more space as many of these matchings share many edges.)

8.2 Running time

In Table¬†4 we present runtimes of all four methods for the datasets considered. Dashes indicate times above one hour. We report user times; the real times are within 2%percent22\% of these in all cases except for¬†OG, where the memory needs for graph and data structures exceeded the RAM available (16Gb), causing excessive disk swapping.

As MF has two clearly differentiated parts, we analyze two different runtimes:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Time to compute the satisfaction probabilities of each user, and the probability of using each edge in the maxmin-fair distribution (step 1, finding the fair decomposition), reported in column MF1subscriptMF1\textsf{MF}_{1};

  • ‚Ä¢

    Total time, including all of the above plus the time to find an edge coloring for each block and the list of matchings for each block (step 2), reported in column MF. (The time to draw a matching given this list, step 3, is negligible.)

No clear pattern emerges as to which of these two phases is faster in practice. As can be observed, in some instances (Vui, Cti, B, Di, de, LG, OG) the time is dominated by the first phase, wheres in others (AM, M3 and WT) the total time is much larger than the time for phase 1 only; in the latter cases the exact requirement of maxmin-fairness forces the algorithm to need a large number of matchings for some blocks, increasing the time for step 2. It seems likely that a more relaxed requirement of approximate fairness could lead to vast improvements in the runtime of step 2.

Similarly, for PS we differentiate between the time to compute the probability of each edge being used (column PS1subscriptPS1\textsf{PS}_{1}), and the total time including the former plus the time to find a distribution of matchings which agrees with those probabilities. However, this last step is much slower in the case of PS because in this case we need to use the full Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition, instead of exploiting the degree regularity conditions of the blocks to find edge colorings as we do for MF. Because existing implementations of the Birkhoff-von Neumann decomposition do not scale even for the smaller graphs tested, we decided to omit the second phase of PS (which is not required to analyze its fairness properties).

As is to be expected, the unfair algorithm¬†UF is the fastest. As for the others, the only one which can be run to completion within one hour in all datasets is ours (MF). Its runtime is usually a handful of seconds except for the very large graphs, where it is in the order of minutes (37 minutes at most, attained for the graph WT). We can see that PS is the most computationally expensive, as many iterations of its main loop are required to reach convergence, and each iteration takes linear time. Finally, the runtime of RP is generally comparable to that of MF on small and medium-size graphs, outperforming it on many of the smaller graphs, but RP becomes slower for larger graphs; despite the additional complexity of MF, the priority mechanism of RP precludes the use of the push-relabel max-flow algorithms, and also limits the number of simultaneous augmenting paths which can be found during a single graph search in augmenting-path algorithms. Notice that these are runtimes for a single run; if the satisfaction probabilities need to be computed then it becomes necessary to run RP a large number of times, slowing it down considerably. (This is not the case for MF or PS.)

8.3 Satisfaction probability comparison

Next we analyze the satisfaction probabilities produced by maxmin-fair matchings (MF) and compare with the probabilistic serial and random-priority mechanisms. Note that the exact determination of the satisfaction probabilities of RP is computationally infeasible. To approximate them, we run RP a total of T=1000ùëá1000T=1000 times with independent uniformly random permutations. (Note, however, that this does not give a good estimate of probabilities below 1/T1ùëá1/T.)

For this comparison we focus on the smaller graphs, due to the limited scalability of PS (which needs a large number of iterations in its main loop, each taking linear time) and RP (which needs to be run TùëáT times to approximate the satisfaction probabilities).

Finally, table¬†5 reports the distribution of satisfaction probabilities: minimum value (ŒªminsubscriptùúÜmin\lambda_{\text{min}}), quantiles, percentage of users with satisfaction 1 (p‚Äãe‚Äãr‚Äã1ùëùùëíùëü1per1), and Nash welfare (N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0}), the geometric mean of utilities (satisfaction probabilities in our setting). Nash welfare is a standard measure of fairness when allocating divisible resources¬†nash_unreasonable . As in¬†gen_nash , we also study the generalization of Nash welfare using power means (for a parameter p‚àà‚Ñùùëù‚Ñùp\in\mathbb{R}):

N0‚Äã(D)=(‚àèu‚ààùí∞D‚Äã[u])1/|ùí∞|,subscriptùëÅ0ùê∑superscriptsubscriptproductùë¢ùí∞ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢1ùí∞N_{0}(D)=\left(\prod_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}}{D}[{u}]\right)^{1/|{\mathcal{U}}|}, (4)
Np‚Äã(D)=(‚àëu‚ààùí∞D‚Äã[u]p|ùí∞|)1/p.subscriptùëÅùëùùê∑superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùí∞ùê∑superscriptdelimited-[]ùë¢ùëùùí∞1ùëùN_{p}(D)=\left(\frac{\sum_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}}{D}[{u}]^{p}}{|{\mathcal{U}}|}\right)^{1/p}. (5)

When p=1ùëù1p=1, Np‚Äã(D)subscriptùëÅùëùùê∑N_{p}(D) is the mean satisfaction probability, which equals œÅ/|L|ùúåùêø\rho/|L| for any Pareto-efficient mechanism. Taking the limit in¬†(5) as p‚Üí0‚Üíùëù0p\to 0 one obtains¬†(4)¬†ineq_book , justifying the notation N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0} for (standard) Nash welfare. Taking the limit as p‚Üí‚àí‚àû‚Üíùëùp\to-\infty yields minu‚ààùí∞‚Å°D‚Äã[u]subscriptùë¢ùí∞ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢\min_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}}{D}[{u}], which by definition is maximized by MF.

Table¬†6 shows these metrics for the three mechanisms tested, on those graphs where PS terminated in 8 hours. Notice that N1‚Äã(MF)=N1‚Äã(RP)>N1‚Äã(PS)subscriptùëÅ1MFsubscriptùëÅ1RPsubscriptùëÅ1PSN_{1}(\textsf{MF})=N_{1}(\textsf{RP})>N_{1}(\textsf{PS}), confirming that MF and RP are Pareto-efficient but PS is not. The generalized welfares for p<1ùëù1p<1 are computed exactly for MF and PS, but estimated from the empirical probabilities after TùëáT samples for RP. (For p=0ùëù0p=0 we replace each empirical probability qùëûq by max‚Å°(q,1/T)ùëû1ùëá\max(q,1/T) so that the estimate is non-zero.) MF comes out on top for all (generalized) Nash welfares in all instances, in accordance with a result of¬†dichotomous . Interestingly, N0‚Äã(RP)subscriptùëÅ0RPN_{0}(\textsf{RP}) is typically within 1% of N0‚Äã(MF)subscriptùëÅ0MFN_{0}(\textsf{MF}) (as both solutions result in a large proportion of users with high satisfaction), but for smaller pùëùp the gap can widen to as much as 22%percent2222\% for p=‚àí5ùëù5p=-5, in accordance with the fact that MF was designed to provide better guarantees to low-satisfaction users.

Table¬†7 shows the expected fraction of satisfied users among the bottom t%percentùë°t\% using each method, for t=1,5,10ùë°1510t=1,5,10, and 202020. Again, our method always gives the highest values, the gap with the second best being as high as 50% in some instances where t=1ùë°1t=1.

Table¬†8 reports the variance of the logarithms of satisfaction probabilities over uniformly random users, as a measure of inequality. (Taking logs penalizes wildly varying ratios of satisfaction probabilities.) We see that MF, which minimizes social inequality in the sense of Def.¬†5, also tends to minimize this quantity in all datasets tested.

9 Related work

To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to study computationally efficient randomized maxmin-fair matching algorithms, and to offer a general definition of fairness for general search problems.

The work of Bogomolnaia and Mouline¬†dichotomous on random matching under dichotomous preferences is closely related to ours: they define an egalitarian solution and show that it is envy-free, strategy-proof and group-strategy-proof with respect the set of right or left vertices. As the authors note, they do not provide an axiomatic characterization of their solution; rather, their definition of egalitarian is expressed in terms of a specific algorithm and is thus not easily generalizable to other search problems. By contrast, our definition of distributional maxmin-fairness applies to any search problem with non-unique solutions and, in the special case of bipartite matchings, is equivalent to the egalitarian solution. In¬†dichotomous two simple algorithms are proposed to find egalitarian matchings, both of them running in exponential time; our work yields a practical polynomial-time algorithm for the problem. We found no efficient algorithms or practical implementations of the egalitarian mechanism prior to our work.

Building on¬†dichotomous , Roth et al¬†kidney propose an egalitarian mechanism for the exchange of donor kidneys for transplant. McElfresh and Dickerson¬†balancing_kidney propose a tradeoff between fairness and a utilitarian objective function in kidney exchange programs. Kamada and Kojima¬†matching_econ study randomized matching mechanisms for the design of matching markets under distributional constraints; their setup contains full bipartite graphs equipped with complete and strict preference relationships. Teo and Sethuraman¬†geometry_matchings prove the existence of a ‚Äúmedian‚Äù deterministic solution to the stable matching problem which is fair to everyone, but finding a polynomial-time algorithm remains an open problem. Cheng¬†generalized_median presents a technique to approximate the median stable matching.

In the area of resource allocation problems, several works investigate the equitable distribution of divisible resources in networks. The work of Ichimori et al¬†optimal_sharing considers a minmax-style optimization function, whereas Katoh et al¬†equipollent considers allocation problems so that the maximum of profit differences is minimized; none of these consider distributions of several solutions. Bansal et al¬†santa_claus give approximation algorithms for the Santa Claus problem, where a number of indivisible presents are to be distributed among kids who have different values for different presents, and the goal is to maximize the minimum happiness of a kid. Bertsimas et al¬†price_fairness introduce the price of fairness in resource allocation problems. A substantial amount of work has also been devoted to cake-cutting algorithms and their strategic and incentive properties: see ¬†fair_division_survey ; better_cake ; cake_soda and the references therein.

Several authors have studied lexicographically optimal flows in networks (which could be used in place of Step 1 of our algorithms): Meggido¬†megiddo designed an algorithm with running time O‚Äã(n5)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ5O(n^{5}), whereas Brown¬†sharing proposed a polynomial-time algorithm requiring nùëõn max flow computations. On the other hand, the parametric flow algorithm of Gallo et al¬†parametric_flow can be used to find fair decompositions with a single max flow, but is not compatible with the max flow algorithm of Goldberg¬†flow_unit . None of these methods can be used to match the runtime of our algorithm to find fair decompositions.

The bulk of the research in the area of algorithmic bias and fairness has mainly focused on avoiding discrimination against a sensitive attribute (i.e., a protected social group) in supervised machine learning¬†fairness_awareness ; FeldmanFMSV15 ; Corbett-DaviesP17 . Most of this literature focuses on statistical parity, or group-level fairness, i.e., the difference in having a positive outcome for a random individual drawn from two different subpopulations (e.g., men and women). Feldman et al.¬†FeldmanFMSV15 propose to repair attributes so as to maintain per-attribute within-group ordering while enforcing statistical parity, so that a single decision threshold applied to the transformed attributes would result in equal success rate among the two different groups. Corbett-Davies et al.¬†Corbett-DaviesP17 reformulate algorithmic fairness as constrained optimization in the context of criminal justice: the objective is to maximize public safety while satisfying formal fairness constraints designed to reduce disparities. Dwork et al.¬†fairness_awareness provide examples showing that statistical parity alone is not sufficient for fairness, and study a randomized solution for classifiers to guarantee that ‚Äúsimilar individuals are treated similarly‚Äù in an expected sense. The idea that more qualified individuals should be chosen preferentially is present in the work of Joseph et al.¬†fairness_bandits , who study fairness in multi-armed bandit problems. Pedreschi et al.¬†PedreschiRT08 introduced the related data mining problem of discovering discrimination practices in a given dataset containing past decisions; if such a dataset is used as training set for a machine learning model, the bias detected can be fixed before the learning phase¬†KamiranC11 ; ZliobaiteKC11 . Heidari et al¬†moral show that many existing definitions of algorithmic fairness, such as predictive value parity and equality of odds can be viewed as instantiations of economic models of equality of opportunity. Heidari et al¬†ignorance study a welfare-based measure of fairness for risk-averse individuals, and derive an efficient mechanism for bounding individual-level inequality.

Finally, maxmin-fairness (in a non-distributional sense) as an objective is used for flow control in networks¬†maxmin_allocation ; data_networks . In the context of non-discrimination, the concept dates back at least to Rawls‚Äôs theory of justice¬†theory_justice , where a ‚Äúdifference principle‚Äù is advocated whereby social and financial inequalities are required to be to the advantage of the worst-off. In Rawls‚Äôs distributive justice, social measures should be designed so as to bring the greatest benefit to the least-advantaged members of society, in order to maximize their prospects.

10 Conclusions

In this paper we study the problem of algorithmic fairness towards the elements that may or not be included in a solution of a matching problem. This is particularly (but not exclusively) important when these elements are humans. Towards this goal, we propose the distributional maxmin fairness for randomized algorithms. A series of theoretical results characterize maxmin-fair distributions and pave the road to our practical contribution: an exact polynomial-time algorithm for maxmin-fair bipartite matching, which scales to graphs with millions of vertices and hundreds of millions of edges. We also discussed methods for the transparent and accountable real-world deployment of our framework.

Regarding future work, it would be interesting to consider notions of approximate fairness intended to deal with optimization problems, where solutions may have different business value, possibly unrelated to satisfaction probabilities. The goal could be to reach a compromise between fairness and expected business value. It would be desirable to be able to find approximately maxmin-fair distributions more quickly than exact maxmin-fair distributions; we leave this as an open problem. Another interesting question is whether our methods can be extended to handle online matching/streaming settings and/or graphs which do not fit into main memory. Finally, future work may consider other notions of fairness for randomized algorithms for people search, people ranking and other learning problems.

Lemma 7.

If FùêπF and Dùê∑D are both minmax-Pareto, then F‚Äã[u]=D‚Äã[u]ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢{F}[{u}]={D}[{u}] for all u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in{\mathcal{U}}.

F‚Äã¬†is minmax-Pareto¬†‚üπD‚Äã[u]>F‚Äã[u].ùêπ¬†is minmax-Pareto¬†ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢F\text{ is minmax-Pareto }\implies{D}[{u}]>{F}[{u}].

But then FùêπF and Dùê∑D cannot both be minmax-Pareto. The only way out of this contradiction is to conclude that Aùê¥A is empty. ‚àé

Theorem A.1.

For matroid problems, a distribution FùêπF is minmax-Pareto if and only if FùêπF is Pareto-efficient and F‚Üì‚™ØD‚Üì{F\downarrow\,}\preceq{D\downarrow\,} for all Pareto-efficient distributions¬†Dùê∑D.

Proof.

First observe that, for matroids, a distribution is Pareto-efficient if and only if it is supported over bases. For any distribution Dùê∑D of bases over a matroid MùëÄM with ground set LùêøL, consider the distribution D‚àósuperscriptùê∑D^{*} of (L‚àñX‚à£X‚àºD)similar-toùêøconditionalùëãùëãùê∑(L\setminus X\mid X\sim D) of bases over the dual matroid M‚àósuperscriptùëÄM^{*}. Then we have D‚Äã[u]+D‚àó‚Äã[u]=1ùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢superscriptùê∑delimited-[]ùë¢1{D}[{u}]+{D^{*}}[{u}]=1 for all u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L, so clearly FùêπF is minmax-Pareto if and only if F‚àósuperscriptùêπF^{*} is maxmin-fair, which (by Theorem¬†3.1) occurs if and only if F‚àósuperscriptùêπF^{*} is lexicographically largest for M‚àósuperscriptùëÄM^{*}, which in turn is equivalent to FùêπF being lexicographically smallest among distributions of bases of MùëÄM, as we wished to show. ‚àé

Our next result asserts that the only obstruction to achieving high satisfaction probability for every user is the existence of a set of users with small rank-to-size ratio. Finding these obstruction sets will enable us to devise a divide and conquer strategy to obtain fair distributions. For instance, in Example¬†1 the obstruction set is given by the set of users {a0,a2,a3}subscriptùëé0subscriptùëé2subscriptùëé3\{a_{0},a_{2},a_{3}\}, which force the maximum satisfaction probability to be no larger than 2323\frac{2}{3}.

Theorem A.3.

Let MùëÄM be a matroid with ground set LùêøL and rank function œÅ:2L‚Üí‚Ñï:ùúå‚Üísuperscript2ùêø‚Ñï\rho\colon 2^{L}\to\mathbb{N}. The maximum satisfaction probability in a minmax-Pareto distribution over MùëÄM is

Œ†‚Äã(M)=max‚Å°{œÅ‚Äã(L)‚àíœÅ‚Äã(X)|L‚àñX|‚à£0‚äÜX‚ääL}.Œ†ùëÄconditionalùúåùêøùúåùëãùêøùëã0ùëãùêø\Pi(M)=\max\left\{\frac{\rho(L)-\rho(X)}{|L\setminus X|}\mid{0\subseteq X\subsetneq L}\right\}.
Proof.

Apply Theorem¬†A.2 to the dual matroid of MùëÄM. ‚àé

An extension of Theorem¬†A.2 allows us to compute the satisfaction probability of every element of LùêøL.

Lemma 9.

Define a sequence of sets B1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,Bk‚Ä≤‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤B^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,B^{\prime}_{k^{\prime}} iteratively by:

We stop when Sk‚Ä≤=‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùëòS^{\prime}_{k}=\emptyset.Then for every i,u‚ààBi‚Ä≤ùëñùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤ùëñi,u\in B^{\prime}_{i}, the satisfaction probability of uùë¢u in a minmax-Pareto distribution FùêπF is Œªi‚Ä≤=œÅ‚Äã(Bi‚Ä≤)|Bi‚Ä≤|subscriptsuperscriptùúÜ‚Ä≤ùëñùúåsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤ùëñ\lambda^{\prime}_{i}=\frac{\rho(B^{\prime}_{i})}{|B^{\prime}_{i}|}.

Proof.

We argue by induction on kùëòk. First, observe that Theorem¬†A.3 implies F‚Äã[u]‚â§Œª1ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢subscriptùúÜ1F[u]\leq\lambda_{1} for all u‚ààLùë¢ùêøu\in L. The expected number of satisfied elements within B1subscriptùêµ1B_{1} cannot be below Œª1‚Äã|B1|subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùêµ1\lambda_{1}|B_{1}| for any Pareto-efficient distribution FùêπF, otherwise we would have the contradiction

œÅ‚Äã(L)=ùîºA‚àºF|A|=ùîºA‚àºF[|A‚à©B1|]+ùîºA‚àºF[|A‚àñB1|]‚Äã<Œª1|‚ÄãB1|+œÅ‚Äã(L‚àñB1)=œÅ‚Äã(L).ùúåùêøsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùê¥ùêπùê¥subscriptùîºsimilar-toùê¥ùêπùê¥subscriptùêµ1conditionalsubscriptùîºsimilar-toùê¥ùêπùê¥subscriptùêµ1brasubscriptùúÜ1subscriptùêµ1ùúåùêøsubscriptùêµ1ùúåùêø\rho(L)=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{A\sim F}|A|=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{A\sim F}[|A\cap B_{1}|]+\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{A\sim F}[|A\setminus B_{1}|]<\lambda_{1}|B_{1}|+\rho(L\setminus B_{1})=\rho(L).

On the other hand,

ùîºA‚àºF[|A‚à©B1|]=‚àëu‚ààB1F‚Äã[u]‚â§Œª1‚Äã|B1|=œÅ‚Äã(B1)subscriptùîºsimilar-toùê¥ùêπùê¥subscriptùêµ1subscriptùë¢subscriptùêµ1ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùêµ1ùúåsubscriptùêµ1\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{A\sim F}[|A\cap B_{1}|]=\sum_{u\in B_{1}}F[u]\leq\lambda_{1}|B_{1}|=\rho(B_{1}) (19)

by linearity of expectation, so the equality F‚Äã[u]=Œª1ùêπdelimited-[]ùë¢subscriptùúÜ1F[u]=\lambda_{1} must hold for all u‚ààB1ùë¢subscriptùêµ1u\in B_{1}. If k=1ùëò1k=1, this shows the result. The rest of the proof is completely analogous to that of Lemma¬†8, except that we use Theorem¬†A.1 and Lemma¬†7 in place of Theorem¬†3.1 and Lemma¬†1. ‚àé

Proof of Theorem¬†3.2.

It suffices to prove the equivalence (1) ‚áî‚áî\Leftrightarrow (2). Inded, if it holds, then a maxmin-fair distribution simultaneously maximizes the minimum satisfaction probability and minimizes the maximum satisfaction probability (among Pareto-efficient distributions), hence it also minimizes the largest difference between two satisfaction probabilities. An easy inductive argument (omitted) shows that the equivalence (1) ‚áî‚áî\Leftrightarrow (3) then follows.

To show that (1) ‚áî‚áî\Leftrightarrow (2), consider the sequence B1,‚Ä¶,Bksubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëòB_{1},\ldots,B_{k} from Lemma¬†8 and the sequence B1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,Bk‚Ä≤‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤B^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,B^{\prime}_{k^{\prime}} from Lemma¬†9. It suffices to show that they are the same sequence in reverse: k=k‚Ä≤ùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤k=k^{\prime} and Bi=Bk+1‚àíi‚Ä≤subscriptùêµùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤ùëò1ùëñB_{i}=B^{\prime}_{k+1-i} for all iùëñi. We proceed from top to bottom, showing by induction that for each value of iùëñi from 1 to kùëòk, Bi‚Ä≤=Bk+1‚àíisubscriptsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤ùëñsubscriptùêµùëò1ùëñB^{\prime}_{i}=B_{k+1-i}. Consider any Z‚ààSi+1=Si‚à™BiùëçsubscriptùëÜùëñ1subscriptùëÜùëñsubscriptùêµùëñZ\in S_{i+1}=S_{i}\cup B_{i}, which may be split into Z=X‚à™YùëçùëãùëåZ=X\cup Y where X‚äÜSi=‚ãÉj<iBiùëãsubscriptùëÜùëñsubscriptùëóùëñsubscriptùêµùëñX\subseteq S_{i}=\bigcup_{j<i}B_{i} and Y‚ààBiùëåsubscriptùêµùëñY\in B_{i}. Proof of Theorem¬†4.3.

This meets the definition of fair separation from Section¬†4.4.

The fact that the fairly isolated sets form a chain is a direct consequence of Lemma¬†11. Finally, assume for contradiction that some fairly isolated set XùëãX exists other than S1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,Sk‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùëòS^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{k}.
